editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: A TreatiÅ¿e of the Nobilitie of the Realme according to the Law.

QueÅ¿tion. Whether the Barony of Aburgavenny, with the title and dignitie be deÅ¿cended unto the Lady, being the Daughter and Heire of the Honourable Hen. Nevill, the late Baron of Aburgavenny, or unto the Å¿peciall heire male, unto whom the CaÅ¿tle of Aburg being antiently the head of hat Barony is deÅ¿cended.
div.p: WHerein are three things conÅ¿iderable.

1. FirÅ¿t this generall TheÅ¿is, whether within the Realme of England, there be any Baronies by Tenure, And whether Baronia Å¿it dignitas annexa â¢ odo (vizt.) whether the heire male ha
â¢ ing the Castle holden per Baroniam Å¿hall
have the title, or the heire generall which hath not the CaÅ¿tle.

2. The Å¿econd is HypotheÅ¿is, whether by former preÅ¿idents it may be Å¿hewed that this Barony of Aburg. hath beene guided by the lawfull deÅ¿cent of the CaÅ¿tle of Aburgavenny, or whether the Å¿ame hath gone to the heires generals Å¿undred from the CaÅ¿tle.

3. The third is, that it is not to bee doubted whether the dignitie of Baron may deÅ¿cend to the heire female (for where Å¿uch Castles, & is holden per Baroniam, and doth deÅ¿cend unto the heire female. There likewiÅ¿e the title, &c. as in many Noble houÅ¿es of this Realme is moÅ¿t evident) but The QueÅ¿tion is whether the title of Baron or BaroneÅ¿Å¿e may deÅ¿cend to the heire female, whereas that fee holden by Barony, is deÅ¿cended to the Heire male or no, and whether the fee to Å¿upport the dignitie may bee Å¿evered from the dignitie.

div.head: A TreatiÅ¿e of the Barons of this Realme.
div.p:
IT is true of Vlpian PublicÃ¨ intereÅ¿t quod ordinum familiarum
que Å¿olva Å¿it, Lib. O Å¿ed Å¿i F. de ventre inÅ¿piciend. Baldwin in la Å¿acraledge divinis reÅ¿cript Ante Nobilit. cap. 6. Which duly conÅ¿idered, is cauÅ¿e that the Å¿peciall heire male of the late Baron deceaÅ¿ed without any affection of honour or humour of ambition deÅ¿ireth to make knowne what things former times obÅ¿erved, hee hath now found to have been conÅ¿idered in Å¿uch like Quaeries; NevertheleÅ¿Å¿e with all humility and loyall dutie hee Å¿ubmitteth himÅ¿elfe to the princely pleaÅ¿ure of the Queenes moÅ¿t excellent MajeÅ¿tie, â¢ n whom is the fountaine of all Nobilitie, and unto the cenÅ¿ure of
the right Honourable the Earle MarÅ¿hall of England, unto whom the juriÅ¿diction and CogniÅ¿ance of the Å¿ame cauÅ¿e by office appertaineth.

But before proofe be produced,1. By what law this Quer. is to be determined. it Å¿hall not bee amiÅ¿Å¿e to conÅ¿ider two principall things, what manner of proofe in theÅ¿e cauÅ¿es is moÅ¿t pregnant, and by what law this controverÅ¿ie might beÅ¿t bee determined. 3.2. Touching the Å¿tate ofour B â¢ renies. Some things are requiÅ¿ite to bee delivered before in generall manner touching the Å¿tate of the Baronies within the Realme, whereby the Querie in hand may be the better apprehended, and receive the more eaÅ¿ie reÅ¿olution.

As touching the firÅ¿t, it is to bee obÅ¿erved, that the dignity of a Baron, and that name given to a degree of Nobilitie, was not uÅ¿uall any where, untill neere the declination of the Rom. Monarchy, and therefore thoÅ¿e parts of the civill Law, which containe the ancient Roman lawes doe affoord Å¿mall proofe of the deciding of this kind of controverÅ¿ie, otherwiÅ¿e then prechance now and then there
are inÅ¿erted Å¿ome generall Å¿entences or axiomes of the law of nature, which may be particularly applied as the occaÅ¿ion Å¿erveth.

Therefore in thoÅ¿e times upon the Å¿undry invaÅ¿ions of thoÅ¿e Northerne people,Goths. Vandalls. which haÅ¿tened the ruine of the Romane eÅ¿tate, when Tenures and it which they call Feuda, had their firÅ¿t originall, divers new dignities of Nobilitie were deviÅ¿ed, and drawne from the Å¿ervice of the field, whereof Å¿ome of them formerly had beene but names of Offices, as may appeare in the Å¿econd booke de feudis, in the title Quis dicatur dux Marchio, &c.

Hee that would not have the controverÅ¿ies moved within the Realme concerning this kind of Dignities to be deterined by the Common law, and yet would that the common cuÅ¿tome of our Countrey Å¿hould direct the Å¿ame, Å¿peakes in my underÅ¿tanding contrary things, for it is a generall Maxime,7. H. 6. Martin. 9. Ed. 4. & 38 H. 8. CuÅ¿tom. B. 59 that the Common cuÅ¿tome of the Realme, is the common law of the Realme. Therefore to affirme that the common uÅ¿age of the Countrey Å¿hould
direct the controverÅ¿ie, and to denie that the common Law Å¿hould determine it is contrary to it Å¿elfe.

That the common Law doth determine this kind of ControverÅ¿ie, it cannot Å¿eeme Å¿trange to him that conÅ¿idereth the generall diviÅ¿ion, whereby the Å¿aid law is diÅ¿tributed into parts,Bracton, lib. 1. cap 5. & 2 de juÅ¿to & jure. EÅ¿t autem jus publicum, & jus privatum. Jus publicum, Bracton diÅ¿poÅ¿eth it, EÅ¿t jus quod ad Å¿tatum Reipub. pertinet & conÅ¿iÅ¿tit in Å¿acris Sacerdotibus & MagiÅ¿tris. Others give a more large Å¿cope to this diviÅ¿ion,Ioachimus HoÅ¿p. de juris arte, lib. 2. de rebus humanis Å¿ive de jur' civil. diÅ¿tributing jus publicum into three parts into Jus civile, jus fecile, & jus queÅ¿tortum.

The firÅ¿t part jus civile, though it be the generall name of the whole Law, yet in this diviÅ¿ion thye doe underÅ¿tand thereby, that part of the Law wherein conÅ¿ideration of many things are had, tending chiefly to the publick good, and wherein perÅ¿ons of men are conÅ¿idered diverÅ¿ly; Dividumtur quin
que formae modis, pro loco, pro facultate, pro ordine, pro jure, pro dignitate. Under that diviÅ¿ion which is in reÅ¿pect of Order, all degrees of perÅ¿ons, Noble
and ignoble are comprehended, and under the diviÅ¿ion, in regard of dignity the Prince, MagiÅ¿trate,Pro ordine. Officers of all kinds are contained.Pro dignitate. The conÅ¿ideration therefore of all degrees of Nobilitie is a part of the Law practiÅ¿ed in every Kingdome, under that diviÅ¿ion which reÅ¿pecteth publicke juÅ¿tice, and therefore in regard of perÅ¿ons Å¿ub ordine debito, this is now apparently perceived if we apply our thoughts to the regard of juriÅ¿diction in generall, which reÅ¿pecteth the fountaine of juÅ¿tice from whom it Å¿pringeth.

All JuÅ¿tice is either commutatiue or diÅ¿tributive. Commutative JuÅ¿tice determineth debates growing upon contracts, inheritance, or chattels, and thoÅ¿e bee reall or perÅ¿onall, which Å¿uites are commenced ad inÅ¿tantiam partis, by Plaint, Bill, or Writ, in the ordinary Court of JuÅ¿tice within the Realme. DiÅ¿tributive JuÅ¿tice is twofold, for either it doth ordaine puniÅ¿hment for Å¿uch crimes as doe fall within the correction of the lawes, or elÅ¿e it doth diÅ¿tribute a reward for vertues. That kind of DiÅ¿tributive
justice that inflicts puniÅ¿hment proceedeth in Å¿ome caÅ¿es ad inÅ¿tant. partis, as in appeales of Murder, Rape, Robery, &c. That moÅ¿t uÅ¿ually Ex officio, and that either by indictment or preÅ¿entment. That kind of DiÅ¿tributive juÅ¿tice which concerneth the advancement of vertue in beÅ¿towing of honour, which is the proper guerdon of vertue,In Camer. Å¿tellat. 39. El. z inter Comit. Kanc. & Rotherom. remaineth with the higheÅ¿t Soveraigne, annexed to the Imperiall Crowne of the Realme, for as vertue is the gift of none but God from heaven, Å¿o the reward of vertue with honour for her MajeÅ¿tie, Gods Å¿ubÅ¿titute on earth within, &c.

But when honour and armes (being the enÅ¿ignes of honour) be once beÅ¿towed on any, or poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed by any, if there Å¿hall ariÅ¿e contention betweene competitors for the Å¿ame, pretending Å¿everall challenge thereto the ancient policie of the Realme, hath ordained an eÅ¿peciall Court,The proper Court of honour & armes. the juriÅ¿diction whereof is immediately derived from the Crowne, and whereof the Judges have beene right honourable perÅ¿onages, The Lord high ConÅ¿table, and
the Earle MarÅ¿hall, and in later times the Judge thereof is the Right Honourable the Earle MarÅ¿hall, the juriÅ¿diction of which Court conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in the execution of that part of DiÅ¿tributive IuÅ¿tice, which concerneth the advancement and Å¿upport of Vertue.

The Court wherein, and the Judges by whom theÅ¿e controverÅ¿ies are to be determined by that which is above. Å¿aid may partly appeare. The Lawes whereby the Å¿ame are to bee decided, are the Lawes of God, the generall concluÅ¿ions of the lawes of Nature,DiÅ¿t. lib. 10. cap 4. Com. 304.6. and of the law of Nations, together with the cuÅ¿tomes & uÅ¿ages of Å¿tatutes and Ordinances of our Countrey in like caÅ¿es heretofore, either obÅ¿erved, or provided, or which are the primary grounds, and chiefe principles of the lawes of this Realme. And if no CauÅ¿e heretofore hath happened that might bee a preÅ¿ident to determine Å¿uch future ControverÅ¿ies, then in the judgement of Å¿uch doubts, that reÅ¿olution is to be imbraced, which is moÅ¿t correÅ¿pondent to our government agreeable with the diÅ¿poÅ¿ition
of our people, and Å¿o eÅ¿pecially as that the new judgement (Å¿o it be promulged) doe not in any matter of conÅ¿equence impeach, infringe, or infeeble any old or former received Law, or uÅ¿age then in force. The law therefore of our Countrey Å¿o branched into Å¿everall Courts, though the Å¿everall JuriÅ¿dictions aforeÅ¿aid, 8. Ed. 4. per Yelverton, Bract. lib. 1. Cap. 2. ought to determine all civill and criminall CauÅ¿es with the body of this Realme concerning whatÅ¿oever CauÅ¿es.

NevertheleÅ¿Å¿e, Å¿ome men there are not duly conÅ¿idering of what principles and parts the Lawes doe conÅ¿iÅ¿t, have laboured to prove that the Quae. of Nobilitie and Armes Å¿hould not bee determined by the lawes of the Realme, framing unto themÅ¿elves many Arguments to prove their AÅ¿Å¿ertion, the chiefe of which arguments are here propoÅ¿ed and anÅ¿wered.

Object. 1 FirÅ¿t, it is Å¿aid that the Lawes of the Realme doe make all the Daughters equally to inherit, but it is not Å¿o in the deÅ¿cent of the Dignities and titles of Honour, and therefore it Å¿eemeth that the Quae. concerning the
deÅ¿cent of dignitie are not determinable by the lawes of the Realme.

To this Argument may bee anÅ¿wered,ReÅ¿olve Bract. li. 2. Cap. 4 fol. 10 & li. 2. ca. 5 fol. 13. Coment. 170. that there are divers inheritances, Å¿ome of things corporall, as lands, tenements, &c. Å¿ome of incorporall framed, not by nature, but by mans policy, and therefore called Iura: the firÅ¿t Å¿ort doe lie in Livery, the other are Å¿uch as doe lie in grant. Of the later Å¿ort there are divers kinds, Å¿ome matters of preceptible profit, as Offices common, &c. Some others are matters chiefly of eaÅ¿e, as wayes and paÅ¿Å¿ages over the land of others; Some other concerne matter of profit and pleaÅ¿ure, as ForreÅ¿ts, Parkes, ChaÅ¿es, Warraines, &c. Others of juriÅ¿diction, as the grant of Courts, others of Priviledges and immunities, as a getter to one and his heires, to be quit of SubÅ¿idies, Dizmez, Quinzems, &c. Others matter of honour, as the dignitie of a Duke, MarqueÅ¿Å¿e, Earle, ViÅ¿count, or Baron, granted to one and his heires generall, or to him and the heires of his bodie.

Inheritance concerning matters of
honour,Cap. 1. Praeterea de prohibita feodi alienatione per Frederes. being things in their nature, participating of Å¿uperioritie and eminency, are not partible in any equalitie among many, and therefore muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿itie deÅ¿cend unto one, and that is unto the eldeÅ¿t Daughter inheritable, where there are no heires males lawfully to challenge the Å¿ame. 23. H. 3. Fitz. Com. 8.

There was a Judgement in the time of H. 3. touching the deÅ¿cent of the Earledome of CheÅ¿ter, after the death of the Earle, who died without iÅ¿Å¿ue male, his SiÅ¿ters being his heire, which Judgement was, that the Å¿aid Earledome Å¿hould be devided as other lands, and not to the eldeÅ¿t, But this Judgement was holden erroneous then. For Bracton, a learned Judge of that age,Braction, lib. 7. fol. 76 de CoÅ¿ercen. thus Å¿eemeth to write thereof (viz.) De hoc autem quod dicitur quod de feodo milit. veniunt in diviÅ¿ione capital. MeÅ¿Å¿uagia, & inter cohaeredes dividuntur; Hoc verum eÅ¿t niÅ¿i capitale MeÅ¿Å¿. Å¿it caput Comitat. propter jus gladii quod dividi non poteÅ¿t, vel caput Baroniae caÅ¿trum vel aliud aedificium, & hoc ideo ne Å¿it caput in plures particulas
dividatur, & jura Comitat. & Baroniar' deveniant ad nihilum per quod deficiat regnum, quod ex Comitat. & Baronibus dicitur eÅ¿Å¿e constitutum. Å¿i autem plura Å¿unt aedificia quae Å¿unt capita BAroniae dividi poÅ¿Å¿unt in Cohaeredes facta electione, Å¿alvo jum aÅ¿Å¿uet. quia cum plura ibi jura Å¿unt quod liber per Å¿e poterit inte gre obÅ¿ervari, quod autem non eÅ¿t in uno ut praedoct' eÅ¿t licet Ã qui buÅ¿dam dicatur. Quod in alijs Regionibus aliquando de conÅ¿uetudine dividatur, Å¿ed quod nunquam dividi videtur in Anglia debeat, nec viÅ¿um fuit contrar', & erit conÅ¿uetudo regionis obÅ¿ervanda ubi haereditas eÅ¿t quae petitur, & perÅ¿onae naÅ¿cuntur quae petunt; Et unde Å¿i dicatur quod in regno Angl. aliquando facta fuit partitio, hoc fuit injuÅ¿tum. Vermon liver d'antiquities Ã placitio, 290 ad placiumt. 301. It is therefore evident that Baronies, &c. doe by the lawes of the Realme deÅ¿cend unto the eldeÅ¿t Copercener, and Judgement given once to the contrary. Thereof Bracton doth rightly accompt to be unjuÅ¿t, his reaÅ¿on is notable; For in as much as the Honour and Chivalty of the Realme doth chiefly conÅ¿iÅ¿t in the Nobilitie, reaÅ¿on
will not that Å¿uch dignities Å¿hould be divided among Coperceners, whereby through multitude the reputation of honour in Å¿uch Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion,Pet. Greg. de repub. lib. 7. cap. 5. and Å¿o divided might bee impaired, as the Å¿trength of the Realme being drawne into many hands with decreaÅ¿e of livelihood by Å¿uch partition Å¿hould be infeebled. In which reÅ¿olution Britton the Baroned BiÅ¿hop of Hereford, Britton, 187. de herit. deviÅ¿. who compiled this Booke in the name, and by the commandment of Ed. 1. accordeth, who delivered this as a Å¿peciall Caveat; En tous caÅ¿es Å¿ont les droits des eÅ¿pees (that which Braecton calleth Ius gladij) gardes de Å¿ole miÅ¿Å¿e & diÅ¿membres, he calleth it Ius gladij, becauÅ¿e Dukes, Earles be at the time of their creation, Cinguntur gladijs gladius autem Å¿ignificat defenÅ¿ione, reginae & patriae; But howÅ¿oever that judgement was given, or whenÅ¿oever, it was nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e very evident that it was Å¿oone redreÅ¿Å¿ed, for if it were given upon the death of Ranulph, the laÅ¿t of the name E. of CheÅ¿ter, who died about 17. H. 3. the Writers about that time doe teÅ¿tifie, that the Earledome
of CheÅ¿ter came wholly to Iohn Scot, the Å¿onne of David Earle of Huntington, and AnguiÅ¿h and of Maude the eldeÅ¿t SiÅ¿ter of the Å¿aid Ranulph. If it were given upon the death of the Å¿aid Iohn Scot, who died without iÅ¿Å¿ue about 24. H. 3. (for in the reports of the Law, the difference of a yeare is no great matter) yet notwithÅ¿tanding the Å¿aid Judgement Å¿tood not in force,Math. Paris MonaÅ¿t. Sancti Albani Chron. 36. for that the Å¿aid King aÅ¿Å¿umed the Å¿aid Earledome into his owne hands upon other Å¿atisfaction made to the SiÅ¿ters Coparceners of the Å¿aid Iohn Scot ne tanta haered tas inter Colos deduceretur. M. 6. H. 8.

That the deÅ¿cent of Dignities and Offices of Honour are determinable by the Common law is made manifeÅ¿t by the great cauÅ¿e concerning the office of the Lo. high ConÅ¿table of England challenged tempore H. 8. by the Duke of Buckingham, and determined by the reÅ¿olution of the Judges, as by a note of that CaÅ¿e extant,Dyer, 285. whereof my Lord Dyer in his Reports hath a memoriall is moÅ¿t evident where the CaÅ¿e ws that Humph de Bohun Earle
of Hertford and EÅ¿Å¿ex, held the Manor of Hatfield Newnham, and Whiting hurst, in com' Glouc' du roy pur Å¿ervice de eant hault ConÅ¿table d' Angl
que mor' tyent iÅ¿Å¿ue 2 files que font particion de meÅ¿me les Maners, & part le office eant Å¿ervic' pur reaÅ¿on de tenure
que deÅ¿cent' al ambu files deÌe exerciÅ¿e pur lour Å¿ufficient deputie (dum Å¿ole' vixerint) mez aprez lour mariage, & fuit deÌe exerciÅ¿e Å¿olement pur le Baron el'eigne, Mes quia Hen. de Bullingb. Ca'ps H. 4.)
que ad eÅ¿pouÅ¿e le puiÅ¿ne a
que le man' de WhittenhurÅ¿t de eant part' de terr' iÅ¿s' ten' fuit allot' pur Å¿a pur port. Another Querie was moved, whether by the unitie of parcell of the tenancy in the King the Å¿aid Office, were not determined, or whether this were in the other SiÅ¿ter, which the JuÅ¿tices reÅ¿olved that the Office had its continuance in the eldeÅ¿t SiÅ¿ter and her heires, of whom the Å¿aid Duke was diÅ¿cended, but becauÅ¿e the exerciÅ¿e of the Å¿aid Office was a Å¿ervice in reÅ¿pect of tenure, the Å¿aid Judges further reÅ¿olved that the King might refuÅ¿e to have the Å¿aid office exerciÅ¿ed, as any
Lord may refuÅ¿e the homage of his Tenant; All which reÅ¿olutions the two chiefe JuÅ¿tices did Å¿ignifie unto the King, according to the names of themÅ¿elves and the reÅ¿t.

Object. 2 Second Objection that by the law of Chivalry, if the Widow of a Duke, Earle, Baron, &c. doe marry with a Knight, EÅ¿quire, or Gentleman, then nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e Å¿hee retaineth her name of honour, whereas the Common Law doth otherwiÅ¿e determine thereof, and therefore they conclude that the common Law doth not determine this kind of controverÅ¿ie concerning the title, names and dignities Noble.

There muÅ¿t be made a diÅ¿-Junction betweene the Å¿trictneÅ¿Å¿e of Law,ReÅ¿olu. and courteÅ¿ie of Ladyes at the Court,14 H. 6.2. & 8. a. for it is a rule in Law, as it is the Å¿ame law of Chivalry, and in that point Å¿o is, and Å¿hould be knowne among the Heraulds, for aÅ¿much as a report of law in that caÅ¿e doth acknowledge it to be taken out of the bookes of Heraulds, 5. Mar. bre. Br. 546. & noÅ¿me 69. ForteÅ¿cue, 100. that Quando mulier nobilis nupÅ¿erit igncb. &c. Of the which ForteÅ¿cue Å¿ometime chiefe JuÅ¿tice of England
yeeldeth a notable reaÅ¿on,Cod lib. 10. de incolis leg. Å¿inal. Mulieres honore maritorum, &c. Å¿in autem minoris ordinis verum? For if Å¿hee be honoured with any title in reÅ¿pect of her Husband, it is reaÅ¿on that after his death Å¿he marrying with an inferiour Å¿ub cujus poteÅ¿tate vivet, that Å¿he Å¿hould bee of like qualitie and reputation as is her Å¿aid Husband. For as Å¿he was inabled by the one, Å¿o muÅ¿t Å¿he be content to leave that Nobilitie by Å¿trict courÅ¿e of law for liue of the other, Å¿o that in this point the law is one way, and the honour and courteÅ¿ie of Ladyes another. And as the Civilian Å¿aith in the like caÅ¿e,6. E. 3.7. E 6.79. 3 Eliz 23.69. Aliud eÅ¿t jus, aliud Privilegium. NevertheleÅ¿Å¿e, the books of our law do make mention of that CourteÅ¿ie, and allow of it as a Courterie though not as the Law.

With theÅ¿e doe agree the law of Nation, with which concordeth alÅ¿o the Civill law, Foeminae nuptae clariÅ¿Å¿imis perÅ¿onis clariÅ¿Å¿. perÅ¿onarum appellatione continuentur. But of the other Å¿ide clariÅ¿Å¿ â¢ oeminarum nomine Å¿enator. Filiae, niÅ¿i quae viros claeriÅ¿Å¿. Å¿ortitae Å¿unt, non habentur. Foeminis enim dignitat.
clariÅ¿Å¿. mariti tribuunt. Parentes verÃ² donec plebeis nuptijs fuerint copulaetae. Cod de dignit. leg 12.
tamdiu igitur clariÅ¿Å¿. foemina erat quaemdiu Senatori nupt. eÅ¿t. vos clariÅ¿Å¿. aut Å¿eparat. ab eo alij. inferioris dign. non nupÅ¿erit.

NevertheleÅ¿Å¿e,Iacob Rebuff ind â¢ ct. leg. 1. lib. 12. Cod de dignitat. in Kingdomes this holdeth not place in the blood Royall, for Si filia Regis nubat alicui Duci vel Comiti dicitur tamen Å¿emper Regalis.

LikewiÅ¿e, the Å¿aid firÅ¿t rule touching the Nobilitie of Women married unto perÅ¿ons ignoable doth faile where they inherit thoÅ¿e dignities. For if a Dukedome, Earldome, or Barony deÅ¿cend unto any woman, who taketh an ignoble man to husband, that husband Å¿hall not debaÅ¿e the wife, having Å¿uch Dignities deÅ¿cended, but rather he in her right Å¿hall beare the title of Å¿uch dignities eÅ¿pecially if he be intituled by the CourteÅ¿ie.

Object 3 A third Object. is this, It is Å¿aid that by the law of Chivalry exerciÅ¿ed within the Realme, if a Baron be created an Earle, &c. that the heire apparent of Å¿uch Earle, &c. Å¿hall after Å¿uch Creation of his Father beare the title
of the Barony, &c. but this is not uÅ¿uall by the courÅ¿e of the Common law: therefore the deÅ¿cent of Å¿uch Dignities not to be guided by the Common Law.

The common law doth not diÅ¿allow any Å¿uch uÅ¿age,ReÅ¿olu. for it being the cuÅ¿tome of the Realme, is the law of the Realme. Howbeit the Common Law doth put a difference betweene Å¿uch Heires apparent as carry thoÅ¿e Titles lawfully in reÅ¿pect of the uÅ¿age, and Å¿uch others as have them by Creation or otherwiÅ¿e, for Å¿uch Heire apparent is no Peere of the Realme as thoÅ¿e by Creation, or Å¿uch as have the Earldome, &c upon deÅ¿cent after the death of his AunceÅ¿tor, and therefore as when the Lord Hen. Howard, Earle of Surry, Son & Heire apparent to Thomas Duke of Norfolke, An Earle by Nativity. was attainted his Triall was by Iury of Knights and Gentlemen, not by Barons, &c. for that hee was an Earle by Nativity, which in reÅ¿pect of tryall the Law doth not allow. The like tryal chanced to the Lord Gray, who 33. H. 8. was in B. K. arraigned of treaÅ¿on, and appointed
to bee tried by a Jury of Knights and Gentlemen, and not by Peeres, CauÅ¿a qua Å¿upra; but he confeÅ¿Å¿ed the Indictment and the Jury were diÅ¿miÅ¿Å¿ed, yet Å¿uch Å¿hall hold precedency of place at Court, and in the preÅ¿ence of their Soveraigne, as is uÅ¿uall in that behalfe.

Obje. 4 It is objected fourthly, that by the Common law a man may not bee called Lord of that he hath not; But by the law of Chivalry a man may bee created Earle of a County, having no land therein: therefore differ.

ReÅ¿ol. 1 It is true that Å¿ome particulars of ordinary proceedings in the law doth differ from other proceedings concerning Chivalry, and yet their difference is no other, then as one hand doth differ from another, both are hands, and both of one body. That part of the law which concemeth purporty, doth not allow a man to bee called Lord of that wherein he is no way owner in demeÅ¿ne or Å¿eignory, but when you draw the law to the conÅ¿ideration of dignity, the whole reÅ¿olution muÅ¿t reÅ¿t upon the Patent
of creation,Earle pur autre vie 31. H 6.29. pur Danby. wherein the name is appointed at the pleaÅ¿ure of the Soveraigne, for one may be Earle during the life of another, if the Creation be Å¿o.

But I anÅ¿wer further, that it is not true that every Earle muÅ¿t be Earle of a place, nor every Earle of a place Earle of a County, nor that every Earle of a County, hath nothing in that County whereby he is Earle. For the better manifeÅ¿tation conÅ¿ider that originally within this Realme Earldome of Counties in the antient EngliÅ¿h Saxon Governours were not onely dignities of honour, but alÅ¿o offices of JuÅ¿tice,Vea. leg. Edgar regis de ConÅ¿il. Lamb. 80. n. 5. for that they did further the adminiÅ¿tration of JuÅ¿tice in the County whereof they were Earles or Aldermen, they likewiÅ¿e had their Deputies under them, the Sheriffe an Officer, yet containing the name of his Å¿ubÅ¿titution in Latine Vicecomes. Camden. 107. TheÅ¿e Earles in recompence of their travailes received a Salary name by the third penny of the profits of the Å¿aid County, which continued long after the ConqueÅ¿t, and was inÅ¿erted
as a princely benevolence in the Patent of Creation, as by divers antient Charters may appeare, which afterward were turned into PenÅ¿ions,H 3. dedit Haber â¢ o de burgo 40 pro 3. deno. Com. Cant. de quoeund creavit comit. habeÌd. Å¿ibi, & haered. de corpore Marger. uaeor Alexand. reg. Scotiae. 13. H 3. in turr. Lond. 33 H. 6.29.6 H. 8. Dy. 2. for the better maintenace of that honour, and as appeareth by a booke caÅ¿e upon the pleading of the Patent, whereby H. 6. Created that worthy Knight, Sir John Talbot Earle of Shrewsbury, which PenÅ¿ion is Å¿o annexed unto their Dignitie, as that by any meanes of alienation it cannot be Å¿evered, and therefore in reÅ¿pect of Å¿uch PenÅ¿ions which were the third part of the profits of the County, or other Å¿umme in lieu thereof, Å¿ome have not without probabilitie imagined, Quod Comites nominabant capiend. fiÅ¿co Regis Å¿ocij & Comites fido participes eÅ¿Å¿ent Lamberd. &c.

Of the Å¿ingle Ear. and not Palentine with Engl there have beene principally two kinds, but every one of them againe Å¿ubdivided into Å¿everall branches, for either they take their names of a place, or hold their Title without any place. ThoÅ¿e that take their names of a place, are of two
kinds, for either the Å¿ame place is a County which is moÅ¿t uÅ¿uall, or elÅ¿e Å¿ome other place and no County, as a Towne, CaÅ¿tle, or honour, &c. of which later Å¿ort Å¿ome are more antient, having their originall even from the ConqueÅ¿t, or Å¿hortly after: as the Earledome of Richmond in YorkÅ¿hire. Clarence in Suff. Arundell in EÅ¿Å¿ex, all which had their originall in the time of the Conquerours by donation of thoÅ¿e CaÅ¿tles, &c. The Earledomes of Bath temp. H. 7. & H. 8. erected in the family where now it remaineth, and the Earledome of Bridgewater, whereof Sir Giles Dawbeney was Created Earle, temp. H. 7. Earledomes which have their titles without any place, are likewiÅ¿e of two kinds, either in reÅ¿pect of office, as is the Earle MarÅ¿hall, for it is granted in this or the like manner. Officium Comit. MareÅ¿cal' Angl' with further words, (vizt.) A.B. &c. Comit. MareÅ¿callum Angl. creamus, ordinamus, &c. by which it appeares that the very office is an Earledome.Earle by birth.

The Å¿econd Å¿ort are Earles by birth,
and Å¿o are all the Sons of the Kings of England, if they have none other dignitie beÅ¿towed upon them, and therefore it is Å¿aid that John afterwards King of England, in the life-time of his Father H. 2. was called Counte Å¿ans terre, before he was affied unto Alice, the Daughter of the Earle of Morton in France.

Object. 5 A fifth Object. is this, The law of Chivalry proceedeth not in the accompliÅ¿hment of a combate in Å¿uch manner as is performed by the courÅ¿e of the Common law, either in the Writ of right by Champion, or in the Appeale by perÅ¿on, therefore the managing of the cauÅ¿es in Chivalry is not in the common law eÅ¿pecially,37. H. 6.36 37. H. 6. foraÅ¿much as our bookes doe acknowledge them to be determined by courÅ¿e of the Civill law.

It is true,ReÅ¿ol. that the manner of performance of thoÅ¿e Å¿everall kinds of Combates is very different, and although the combate for Honour, or upon the Appeale for treaÅ¿on be performed within England, according to the cuÅ¿tome of forraigne Nations in
Å¿ome reÅ¿pects, although not altogether Å¿o, that almoÅ¿t every particular Countrey hath a particular manner, by meanes whereof Å¿ome men Å¿eeing the difference betwixt thoÅ¿e and the ordinary courÅ¿e of obÅ¿ervance of Combates for land in the Writ of right, or for life in the Appeale of felony, have therefore imagined that the proceeding in Combate before the Lord ConÅ¿table or Lord MarÅ¿hall in the Appeals of treaÅ¿on, or in cauÅ¿es of Honour betwixt Å¿uch perÅ¿ons,Paris de Putio Iohannes de delignatio Iac. de CaÅ¿tilio And. AÅ¿Å¿iatus. Iul. Herret. Anthon. MoÅ¿Å¿eus, Cod. lib. 21. gladiatus lege unica. Dig lib 9. ad legem aqualiam, leg. 7. JuÅ¿tus LipÅ¿ius de gladiatoribus. as by the law may wage the Å¿ame, Å¿hould be according to the courÅ¿e of the Civill law, yet nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e it muÅ¿t been certaine that the Civill law of the Romanes, is Å¿o farre off from giving any allowance thereto, as that it Å¿eemeth to forbid it. For that law of the ChriÅ¿tian Emperour ConÅ¿tantine is moÅ¿t notably alledged to this purpoÅ¿e by moÅ¿t of the learned Doctors of the Civill law, that have written De duello, the words of which law are theÅ¿e, Cruenta Å¿pectacula in otio civili & domeÅ¿t. quiete non placent. And that which for diÅ¿putation Å¿ake
is alledged to the contrary. Si quis in colluÅ¿tratione vel pancratio vel pugiles dum inter Å¿e exercenturs alius alium occideret. Si quidem in publico certamine alius alium occiderit ceÅ¿Å¿at, equalia, quia gloriae cauÅ¿a, & virtutis non injuriae gratia vitetur damnum datum, is underÅ¿tood rather of JuÅ¿ts and Å¿uch like playes de gladiatoribus, as were uÅ¿uall among the Romanes, all which were abrogated by this law of ConÅ¿tantine. I. de Lignano de Duel. a 5. Inlius Ferret. de duel. n. 20.5. Andr. AÅ¿cicus de du

NevertheleÅ¿Å¿e among theÅ¿e warlike Nations that invaded the Romane Empire this kind of Å¿ingle Combate hath beene againe exerciÅ¿ed in divers Kingdomes, according to the cuÅ¿tome of every Å¿everall Countrey. Among the Lumbards it, was permitted in 19 caÅ¿es; Their weapons being nothing elÅ¿e but the Shield and the BaÅ¿ton. And yet of the uÅ¿e, or rather abuÅ¿e therreof, the King Katharius Å¿eemeth to complaine, purpoÅ¿ing to have abrogated the Å¿ome. Quia incerti Å¿umus de judicio dei, & multos audivimus per pugnam Å¿ine juÅ¿ta cauÅ¿a Å¿uam cauÅ¿aem perders, Å¿ed propter conÅ¿uetua. gentis noÅ¿tre Longobardor.
legem impiam vetare non poÅ¿Å¿umus In the Å¿everall Kingdomes of Cicilie in Spaine, it hath beene allowed in Å¿ome CaÅ¿es; LikewiÅ¿e in France by the conÅ¿titution of Philip le Beau. Anno 1306. LikewiÅ¿e the Emperour Fredericke did permit it in certaine caÅ¿es expreÅ¿Å¿ed in the TreatiÅ¿e De conÅ¿uetud. feodorum in the title De Pace tenenda & ejus violatoribus Å¿i quis hominem, Å¿i quis alium, Å¿i quis Miles, &c. In Å¿ome places of Italy the battell hath beene allowed upon leÅ¿Å¿e occaÅ¿ion,De pugn. cern. cap. 4. in fine. of the which Alciatus maketh mention with Å¿ome deteÅ¿tation.

Hereof it is evident that the order, manner, and cauÅ¿es of Å¿ingle Combate are different in divers Countries, and every Countrey: that people following their owne CuÅ¿tomes and uÅ¿ages being their peculiar Law: and in this our Realme, it was a tryall much more frequented in antient times neere the ConqueÅ¿t then Å¿ucceeding ages, for it is evident by Å¿ome antient Records and Plea rolls yet extant of King Steven, Wager of battell in perÅ¿onall cauÅ¿es. H. 2. R. 1. and King Iohn, that it was permitted to be waged in
perÅ¿onall occaÅ¿ions in caÅ¿es wherein men now commonly wage their law, 37. H. 6. fol 36.37. H. 6. fol. 20. Glan. lib. 8. cap 8. Que battalle partee gage en aÅ¿cun caÅ¿e en vn' bre. de fac. Iudgement. and therefore in 37. H. 6. and 37. H. 6. fol. 20. Needehams opinions are much more agreeable to the truth, where both doe affirme that Å¿uch waging of battell before the Lord high ConÅ¿table and Earle MarÅ¿hall, is by the Lawes of this Realme, although it bee determined before them, and Å¿o great a Sympathy is betweene that Court and others of common JuÅ¿tice, as that the Judges Å¿hall take notice of the proceedings before the Lord ConÅ¿table and Earle MarÅ¿hall upon occaÅ¿ion offered riÅ¿ing in debate before them.

Object. 6 The Å¿ixth Objection is this, The common Law in the trials of matters in Å¿entence doth proceed by a Jury of 12. but the law of Chivalry in the triall of matters in fact concerning Honour and ARmes proceedeth upon examination of witneÅ¿Å¿es, which is according to the courÅ¿e of the civill Law: therefore matters of Honour are to bee determined by the civill (not common) Law.

I the tryall of matters in fact,ReÅ¿olu. the
common law doth not alwayes proceed by a Jury, for although they moÅ¿t properly lye in the ConuÅ¿ance of the Jury,8. Ed
â¢â¢ triall 94. 9 Ed 2. Iudg meÌt, 231. yet in other matters the Law hath ordained Å¿ome other manner of tryall, as they gage others by WitneÅ¿Å¿es, as if a Wife bring a Writ of Dower, Å¿uppoÅ¿ing her Husband to bee dead, and the tenant Å¿aith that he is alive, whereupon they arer at iÅ¿Å¿ue, this Å¿hall be tried by WitneÅ¿Å¿es only, and not by Jury.33. H. 6.9. 35. H. 6.47 So likewiÅ¿e if land be recovered by default, and after brings a Writ of diÅ¿cript, for that hee was not lawfully Å¿ummoned in the former action, upon which they are at iÅ¿Å¿ue,13. Ed. 1.36.37. 13. H 7. vill 43.47. H. 3 15. Ed 2. Coron 385. Vill. 3 â¢ .19. H. 6.32. this Å¿hall be tried by examination and depoÅ¿itions of the Å¿ummoners, &c. and not by the Jury. In a Write de Nativo habendo, whereby the Plaintife claimeth the Defendant to bee his villaine, the Defendant Å¿aith hee is a freeman, and thereupon they are at iÅ¿Å¿ue, this Å¿hall not be tried by a Jury, but by WitneÅ¿Å¿es, namely Å¿uch males as be of the blood and kindred of the Defendant and not otherwiÅ¿e.48. Ed. 3. n. 34. H 2. 46. E. 3.

Some matters of tryall in fact are
tried by view and inÅ¿pection of the Court,8. Account. 121. & not by a Jury as the Nonage of the Plaintife or defendant alledging himÅ¿elfe to be within the age of twenty one yeares.

And the like tryall is of a Maykem,21. H. 7 33. 39. E. 3.32. 7. H 4.24. 38 E. 3 27. 18 E. 4 36. 2 H 4.17. 22. H 6.27. wherras in an Appeale of Maykem the parties bee at iÅ¿Å¿ue, whether the hurt be a Maykem or no, Å¿ometimes the Courts of the ordinary of Å¿ome other Iudge or Officer, as in matters Å¿pirituall by Certificate thereof from the ordinary, &c. And concerning matters done beyond the Seas in the Kings Army, or concercerning Combate for honour, armes, &c. by Certificate of the Lord ConÅ¿table or Earle MarÅ¿hall,3 H 6.6. 48 E. 3.3. &c. whereby appeareth the weakneÅ¿s of the former Argument, but in caÅ¿es uÅ¿uall the law alloweth the triall by WitneÅ¿Å¿es without Iury; And therefore in the Lord ConÅ¿table and Earle MarÅ¿hals Court matter in fact concerning Honour and Armes (which lie not in the knowledge of the vulgart Å¿orz) the the Common Law grounded upon the beÅ¿t reaÅ¿on would it Å¿hould be tried
by witneÅ¿Å¿es or matters of Record, as the cauÅ¿e Å¿hall require, and not that the Å¿ame Å¿hould be tried by the conÅ¿cience of the vulgar people,22. AÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿. pl. 24. being matters whereof they have no knowledge Å¿ufficiently to diÅ¿cerne.

Hitherto have I wandred of purpoÅ¿e, to Å¿hew that our homebred Law is Å¿ufficiently able, and ought to trie all cauÅ¿es civil (other then Marine) Å¿uch as are riÅ¿ing with the body of the Realme (and not in forraigne parts) whereby appeared the excellencie of the Common Law, which maintaineth the particular juriÅ¿diction of every particular Court. For it is the common Law (through the Å¿undry Writs of prohibition which it uÅ¿eth) which keepeth every Court within the compaÅ¿Å¿e of his proper Å¿phere, and upholdeth the juriÅ¿diction of the Court of the Earle MarÅ¿hall. By that therfore which hath beene Å¿aid, two things may Å¿ufficiently appeare.

FirÅ¿t, that the Court of the Lord ConÅ¿table and Earle MarÅ¿hall have had, and now the Earle MarÅ¿hals Court hath particular juriÅ¿diction originally
and primarily to determine matters of controverÅ¿ie concerning Chivalry, Dignity, Honour & Armes, and Å¿ome other things acknowledged to belong to the Å¿aid Court by the Lawes and Statutes of our Countrey.

Howbeit by a conÅ¿equent but not originally, Å¿ome other Courts of ordinary juÅ¿tice may, as the caÅ¿e Å¿hall require, determine likewiÅ¿e Å¿uch like controverÅ¿ies touching honour, &c. but not (eaÅ¿e or in Å¿ua) but rather by an adjunct, as by this example may appeare. If there bee two competitiours of a Barony, and during the time that their cauÅ¿e is litigious, the one of them is impleaded at the common Law by originall Writ Cap. alz & plures in a perÅ¿onall action, and thereupon an exigent is awarded, whereupon inÅ¿ueth an Outlary, the party outlwaed brings a Writ of errour, and aÅ¿Å¿igneth for errour, that hee having Å¿uch a CaÅ¿tle to him deÅ¿cended, &c. holden per Baroniam, whereupon his AnceÅ¿tours have beene Barons, anp he himÅ¿elfe Baron, no Cap. ought to be awarded againÅ¿t him, but in very Å¿peciall caÅ¿es onely,
therefore the outlary erroneous. This matter of errour alledged, the Court cannot conÅ¿ider without due determination of the title of the Barony, wherein if the Court of the Earle MarÅ¿hall Å¿hould adjudged one way by any forraigne Law in the Å¿ame queÅ¿tion depending there, and the Court of B.R. adjudge another way by the common law of the Realme: upon this Writ of errour, there would enÅ¿ue thereof a great confuÅ¿ion and inconveniencie in the Common-wealth, which the law will rather eÅ¿chew then any other miÅ¿chiefe whatÅ¿oever.

Secondly, therefore it doth appeare by the Å¿peeches aforeÅ¿aid, that the common law ought to decide this controverÅ¿ie, and that both Courts ought to follow one and the Å¿ame law, in as much as the common law is more ample then ordinary reports of CaÅ¿es in the yeare bookes. For whatÅ¿oever is not diÅ¿agreeing from the law of God, and is conÅ¿onant to the lawes of nature and Nations, allowed by the cuÅ¿tomes of our
Countrey not diÅ¿agreable to former preÅ¿idents anÅ¿werable to all good learning is the vndoubted common law of the Realme, which knowledgeth no other Author but God and nature, and whereof the Iuges in all ages have ever thought it honourable to receive all good helpes from every faculty of literature in the ending of difficulties queÅ¿tioned before them.

The proofe therfore in this controverÅ¿ie to be produced Å¿hall be arguments of reaÅ¿on,What maÌ ner of proofes are to be uÅ¿ed in your ControverÅ¿ies. allegations of authoritie, preÅ¿idents of time drawne out of Records, HiÅ¿tories, ouncient Monuments, Lawes and cuÅ¿tomes of our owne countrey and furniÅ¿hed with Å¿uch other matters of neceÅ¿Å¿ary knowledge as may tend to the better explanation.

It followeth Å¿omewhat to Å¿peake in generall of the dignitie and degree of a Baron,The 2. matters before propoÅ¿ed. whereby the Qu. in hand may be the better conceived and be reduced to a more cleere determination, which for order Å¿ake I will reduce to the conÅ¿ideration of theÅ¿e principall heads.

div.head: The definition or deÅ¿cription of a Baron.
div.p:
IT is a rule of Law that Om nis definitio in jure periculoÅ¿iÅ¿Å¿ima. Dig. l. 51. de regulis juris 203. omnis defifinitio. Rarum eÅ¿t enim ut non Å¿ubverti poÅ¿Å¿it. And therefore I doe not often Å¿ee any definition or deÅ¿cription of a Baron. Baldus thus deÅ¿cribeth a Baron,Baldus Canotus de Å¿ectionibus. vt Å¿it quiÅ¿quis merum mixtum
que imperium in aliquo CaÅ¿tro opidove conceÅ¿Å¿ione principes habeatur, But his Å¿eemeth rather particular to Å¿ome then generall to all, and therefore Alciatus vÅ¿eth theÅ¿e words Nobis alia eÅ¿t sententia quia Å¿ciamus et in Germania, Andr. Alciatus de duello, c. 32. Refer. Pet. Greg. in reg jur. H. 6. capire 10.
et Gallia Å¿olum Barones dici quibus Å¿uper opidorum juriÅ¿dictionem haec dignitas Å¿pecialiter conceÅ¿Å¿a eÅ¿t. Some thinke they are thoÅ¿e which are meant under the name of Æ²alvaÅ¿ores majores & Capitanei. In the Å¿econd booke De feodis de titulo Quis dicatur dux, &c. And Å¿ome others would have the dignitie of a Baron to containe every noble dignitie under the Earle.Grand de Å¿upplenda neglig. plator. in Sexto. Some common Lawyers there are which extoll the dignitie
of a Baron before that of the Earles, by reaÅ¿on of a Å¿ubcription to a decretall epiÅ¿tle directed Baronibus & Comit. regin Portugal. They not conÅ¿idering that in another place in the Å¿ame decretals it is more orderlie placed, Nullus Imperator Å¿eu Rex Romanus aut alius Imper. aut Rex, princeps Marchio, Dux, Comes aut Baro, &c. Other Å¿ome do equal the Baron with the Earle,Baro. de Tan. Berg. refer. Hyard. in Leuxiris. affirming that Comiti Baro. prorÅ¿us equiparatur, &c. nulla
que differentia niÅ¿i quod de Comitat. non Å¿it inveÅ¿ttitus, &c. haud quicquam Comite cenÅ¿eatur inferior. And thus every one of them have written conformably to the cuÅ¿tomes of his particular Countrey.

But in this our Common-wealth of England (me thinkes) a Baron may be deÅ¿cribed in a generality anÅ¿werable to every of the Å¿peciall kinds thereof in this maner.A Baron deÅ¿cribed. A Barony is a dignitie of Nobilitie and honour next vnder the ViÅ¿count, and above the Banaret and VavaÅ¿our with the title of LordÅ¿hip holding the Å¿ame place with vs as did the Patritij or Senatour under the
Romanes. For the better vnderÅ¿tanding whereof conÅ¿ider that Nobilitas generally Å¿ignifieth matter of note, but Å¿pecially it is applyed to expreÅ¿Å¿e the reward of vertue in honourable meaÅ¿ures. Sc. generis claritatem of which there are two kinds Nobilitas major (viz) a Lord at leaÅ¿t, & Nobilitas minor: but our engliÅ¿h tongue expreÅ¿Å¿eth the higher kinde. A Barony therefore is a dignity of nobility and honour. A dignitie of Nobilitie to exclude all other kinds of dignities, of honour, to exclude the leÅ¿Å¿er kind of Nobilitie wherein Gentlemen are comprehended. Dignities of Nobilities are with vs of two kinds Å¿ome are dignities of Nobilitie, honour, parcell of the name of thoÅ¿e that are innobled thereby, Å¿o that in publicke proceedings of law it is parcell of their name, and may not more be omitted then their Å¿urname, Å¿uch are the Nobilitie of Dukes, Earles, Vicounts. Others are Dignities onely,and not parcell of the name, and Å¿o is the Baron, and therefore if an Action bee brought by or againÅ¿t a Baron, who
hath but a Barony onely, it is not requiÅ¿ite to make him Baron, which in all other Dignities being parcell of the name is otherwiÅ¿e moÅ¿t curiouÅ¿ly obÅ¿erved,8. H. 6.10. 32. H. 6.30 Littlet. otherwiÅ¿e the Writ Å¿hall abate; Thus much of the Dignitie of a Baron, now of the Etimologie of the Name.

div.head: 2. The Etimologie of the name Baron.
div.p:
MAny Writs have laboured to yeeld the Etimologie of the name wherein following their owne fancy there hath beene bred much varietie of opinion, Å¿ome men inducing the Greeke, importing Gravity, others have Å¿ought a Latine Author to father it upon,Lib. 5. alledging Cicero ad Atticum, where they find printed in Å¿ome Copies theÅ¿e words, Apud Patronem & reliquos Barones te in maximam graÌ poÅ¿itum, where in other Copies in lieu thereof is read Barrones, Alciat. lib. 5. cap. 16. & 32. and Å¿o by others the Å¿ame is acknowledged to be nothing but a corruption whereof
Alciatus Å¿peaketh, &c. And therfore RaÅ¿ius calleth the word VanaÅ¿ors & vaÅ¿Å¿allos, among the which they intended Barons to be included,Sim. Shaldus in lexico juris, Ptol. lib 2. cap. 6. Io Brekins de conÅ¿uetud. gallorum. Vocabula illota. Others would derive the word from a certaine war-like auncient people inhabiting Å¿ome parts of Spaine, called Barones; or as Strabo and Ptolomy doe name them Barones, whoÅ¿e habitation was Å¿cituate vpon the WeÅ¿t-Å¿ide of the River Euberus, who guarded the perÅ¿ons of the Romane Governours, as the Switzers are now vÅ¿ed for the guarde of certaine Princes. Others derive the name from the manner of building of thoÅ¿e houÅ¿es that were given to Barons to be holden and were the head of their Baronies,Petr. Gregor. Syntax. lib. 6. c. 10.
Quod erant ejuÅ¿modi domus undi
que occluÅ¿ae & Å¿ubÅ¿tructis turribus & barris. Some thinke it to be an Hebrew name Å¿ignifying mercenary Å¿ouldiers, Å¿ome would fetch it meerely from the Latine, Barones tanquam pures homines; But the moÅ¿t probable derivation is drawne from the Northerne peoples language, which invaded the Romane Empire, among
whom a Baron Å¿ignified a man of Å¿trength, as by the lawes of the Lombards, and as by the words yet remaining without much variation in every one of the Å¿aid three tongues, The word Varon and Baron, Tit. 8 in al. lib. tit. 9. Tit. 60.54. is vÅ¿ed in Å¿tead of the Latine word Vir, and with this agreeth parcell of the auntient law of Canutus, Quod eÅ¿t Å¿umma cenÅ¿us diverÅ¿arum dignitatum Å¿i minoris Vironis, id eÅ¿t, Baronis duae librae: Å¿i majoris 4. &c. And therfore in the Lombards lawes, compiled by K. Rotharis the word Baron is thus vÅ¿ed Å¿i quis ex Baronibus noÅ¿tris ad nos voluerit venire, Å¿ecurus veniat & illaeÅ¿us ad Å¿uos revertatur. And in thoÅ¿e old lawes called, Repnaria Å¿i quis hominem regni tabularium tam Barone qui foeminam abÅ¿tulerit, &c. Where the word doth Å¿ignifie the Å¿ame that the word Vir doth in Latine;Vir leges Å¿alvos: Bracton. lib. 2. c. 8. Therefore Bracton not vnfitly vÅ¿eth it Å¿unt & alij potentes Å¿ub rege qui dicuntur Barones (hoc eÅ¿t) robur belli.

div.head: The Antiquitie of the dignitie of Barons and the Å¿undry uÅ¿es of the name.
div.p:
IT Å¿eemeth that the dignitie was more auncient then the name for in the auncient conÅ¿titution feudall of the Lombards, Lib 2 feud. titulo. 10. lib feud. 1.16. lib. 1. feud 1.7. there is not mention made of the name of Baron, howbeit the learned Interpreters underÅ¿tand that dignitie to be comprehended under ValvaÅ¿ores minores, or ValvaÅ¿ini, or ValvaÅ¿ores minimi, being another kind inferiour to Valv. majores, which were alÅ¿o called Capitanei (Barons.) The like Dignitie before the ConqueÅ¿t,Lamb. de regimine Saxonum, fol. 71. of whom is mention made in the Lawes of K. EthelÅ¿ton, and of this there were two kinds Thani Regis & Thani aliorum, Lamb. de regimine Saxon. fol. 71. and therefore in the Records of DoomeÅ¿day in the deÅ¿eription of HertfordÅ¿h. and therein of the Mannor of Brackins it is thus written;Record of Doomes-day HertfordÅ¿hire. Hoc maner' tenuel 2. taggas horum unus homo regis Edw. & alter AÅ¿gari Å¿teleri. This word Thani was diverÅ¿ly uÅ¿ed by the antient Saxons; Sometimes they Å¿ignified
thereby a Noble man, as by the Baron, Å¿ometimes a freeman, Å¿ometimes a MagiÅ¿trate, Å¿ometimes a Å¿ervant attendant upon a mans perÅ¿on, which they Å¿ignified by the Å¿ubÅ¿cription of the antient regall Charters by the word MiniÅ¿ter, as Ego miniÅ¿ter A. B. praeÅ¿ens auÅ¿cultavi or interfui, or in inÅ¿pexi of the Kings Thanis. I find thus much written in the Å¿ame Records, Thanis vel Miles Regius dominicus moriens pro relevamento dimittebat regi omnia arma Å¿ua, & equum unum cum Cella, & alterum Å¿ine cella. quod Å¿i eÅ¿Å¿ent ei canes vel accipitres preÅ¿entabunt regi ut Å¿i vellet acciperet. That the like was done alÅ¿o by the Thanis of others, as of Noblemen, Earles, and others, appeareth by an antient Saxon TeÅ¿tament of one Arfrie an Earle, which is brought to light by MaÅ¿ter Lambert, in the deÅ¿cription of Mephem in the preambulation of Kent in thoÅ¿e times. The Thanis were for the moÅ¿t part deemed Noble, and held one and the Å¿ame dignitie, as the Barons doe. The word Thanis being uÅ¿uall in that Å¿ence, not
onely among our EngliÅ¿h Saxons, but alÅ¿o with the Scots and Danes, as concerning the Scots Hector Poet writeth, Malcolmum regem titulo Comitatum honeÅ¿taÅ¿Å¿e, And as touching the Dane; the Thanis among them are yet in uÅ¿e, as liberi Domini, Å¿uch as are the Barons, by this it may appeare, that the name of Baron was not uÅ¿uall amongÅ¿t the ancient EngliÅ¿h Saxons, for that in the Å¿ubÅ¿cription unto the graunts of Kings, whereunto with the Å¿igne of the X were Å¿ubÅ¿cribed the names of all noble perÅ¿onages, as well temporall as Å¿pirituall, the Å¿aid word Baron cannot bee heard of, but in an antient Charter made in the name of Zolpher, Å¿ometimes King of Mercia, unto the Church of Peter-borough, having theÅ¿e words; Praecipimus quod praedict. MonaÅ¿t. & dona Å¿ua Å¿int habenda, &c. ab omni diminutione & exact. comitum, &c. LikewiÅ¿e to this effect have I Å¿eene in an old booke belonging to the MonaÅ¿t. of WeÅ¿t. Edg. Rex concilio habito infra baÅ¿ilicum WeÅ¿tm. preÅ¿idente eo cum filio Å¿uo Edw. & DunÅ¿tano ArchiepiÅ¿copo, &
univerÅ¿is EpiÅ¿c & Baronibus Å¿uis dictaÌ EccleÅ¿iaÌ de Westm. renovavit. NevertheleÅ¿Å¿e, the name of Baron was not much vÅ¿ed within the Realme untill the Norman ConqueÅ¿t, after which it grew very frequent. In which time the notable caÅ¿es, &c. of the Realme were debated before him and his Barons, and by them adjudged as by divers Monuments extant may appeare,Doomes-day in Canterbury. whereof one is in this manner in the Record of Doomes-day,21. E. 3.6. Quidam PrepoÅ¿it Brumanus eo tempore R. Edw. coepit conÅ¿uet. de extraneis mercatoribus, &c. AlÅ¿o 21. Ed. 1. doth Å¿et forth by exemplification an act of Parliament made in a cauÅ¿e between the Abbot of Saint Edmondsbury, and ArfaÅ¿t Å¿ometimes BiÅ¿hop of Thetford, which See was afterwards tranÅ¿lated by Herbert to Norwich concerning the ViÅ¿itation of the Å¿aid MonaÅ¿terie, which Parliament was holden by the Å¿aid King, the ArchbiÅ¿hop of Cant, BarkÅ¿hire. and all other the BiÅ¿hops, Earles, &c. appeareth. Moreover in the Record of Doomes-day, in the deÅ¿cription of DoneÅ¿h is declared, that at the time of the Å¿aid
Record there were at Warham of certaine Barons lands twenty houÅ¿es Å¿tanding and Å¿eventy deÅ¿troyed, by which appeareth that both name and dignitie of a Baron was Å¿ufficiently knowne in the time of the ConqueÅ¿t, and as touching the vÅ¿e of the name the word Baron Å¿eemeth to be frequented among the Norman Conqu. of this Realme. In lieu of the word Thane among the Saxons, for as they in a large Å¿ignification did Å¿ometime uÅ¿e the Å¿ame to the Å¿ence, &c. of a free man borne of free parentage, &c. and Å¿o did the Normans vÅ¿e it, and therefore called their free Citizens of their beÅ¿t eÅ¿teemed Cities and BurgeÅ¿Å¿es, &c. by the name of Barons,Bracton 272. and therfore the Citizens of London were called Barons Lond. in divers auntient Monuments, of whom alÅ¿o Bracton writeth, Per Barones Lond. &c. So alÅ¿o there are diverÅ¿e Charters wherin mention is made of Å¿uch like Barons as the Barons of Warw. in DoomÅ¿-day, and in our time the BurgeÅ¿Å¿es of the five ports are called Barons, and divers of the Nobility of Barons as well Å¿pirituall
as temporall, did in antient time Å¿et in the Exchequer in judicature. Moreover as our Saxons had two kinds of Thanis;
Fleta, lib. 2. cap. 24. the judges of that Court have been from antient times, and yet are called Barons of the Exchequer. the like hath been obÅ¿erved of Barons among the Norman Conqu. for the Kings of this Realme have had their immediate Barons being the Peeres of this Realme: Å¿o certaine other Noblemen, eÅ¿pecially the Earle Palatine and Earle Marchers, whoÅ¿e Counties have confined upon the coaÅ¿ts of the enemie, have had under them a kind of Barons, as namely under the County Palatine of CheÅ¿ter were theÅ¿e Barons, the Barons of Hatton, Monbatte, Mulbanke, Shipbrooke, Malpas, MaÅ¿y, KingderÅ¿ton, Stockport, &c. The Earle-dome of Pembrooke, being firÅ¿t erected by Arnulphus Mountgomery, 7 H. 6.35. 17. E. 3. inter placita. 18. E. 2. AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿. 30. Camois. that conquered Å¿ome part of the County, and therefore the Earle thereof being an Earle Marcher had alÅ¿o under him his Barons, for it appeareth by the Parliament rolles 18. E. 3. that the Baronies of Haverford, Cammois, Rochie, and CaÅ¿tlegoton, were antiently belonging to the
IuriÅ¿diction of the Earledome of Pembrooke, and had their Chancery and Scals as other Barons upon the Marches vÅ¿ed to have. Hereof alÅ¿o it followed not onely in this Realme, but alÅ¿o elÅ¿e-where, that Earles had under them Å¿uch as they called their Barons, who held under them lands in Knights Å¿ervice and in the defence of their Lords, and therefore in the RegiÅ¿ter of the MonaÅ¿t, of Saint Iames of Northampton, it is found that Simon Ea. of Northampton, did get and confirme unto the Å¿aid Abbey, Omnia dona, &c. quae Barones Å¿ui, &c. infra burgum & extra North. illis dederunt. Many old Charters alÅ¿o are extant, whereby it appeares which now time hath worne out of memory, and yet the knowledge thereof Å¿erveth to good purpoÅ¿e, namely to reconcile the different opinion of Å¿ome men concerning the law,20. E. 3. AÅ¿Å¿. 122. for 20. E. 3. Thorpe holdeth opinion that none can hold per Baron. but of the King onely, and that no Å¿ubiect can aliene his land to another to hold of Å¿uch alienor per Baroniam, which Å¿ome Serjeants
denyed, to the which opinion of Serjeants Wilby and other judges agreed, 2. E. 3. AÅ¿Å¿. 124. Prerog. cap 7. Adding further, that before the Å¿tatute of Prerog. Regis, thoÅ¿e that held per Baroniam might aliene Å¿ome parcell thereof to bee holden by other, Å¿ince which is evident (Å¿aith he) in this that the antient Baronies doe conÅ¿iÅ¿t moÅ¿t of Å¿ervices which began by occaÅ¿ion of Å¿uch Å¿uites as aforeÅ¿aid. The aÅ¿Å¿ertion of both the Å¿aid Iudges is good law, for none can hold per Baroniam but of the K. Qu. &c. Monarchs of the Realme, And againe it is true that in Å¿ome kind of feme a man may hold per Baron. of a Å¿ubject but diverÅ¿is reÅ¿pect. ergo, diÅ¿tinguenduÌ eÅ¿t. None can hold per Baroniam as a Peere of the Realme, and in courÅ¿e of perfect Nobilitie but of the Crowne onely. For of this Bar. Bracton underÅ¿tandeth when he Å¿aith it is the Å¿trength of the Realme, and theÅ¿e Barons according to the law Senderl, are theÅ¿e, Capitanei or ValvaÅ¿or. Majores there Å¿poken of: for Qui a principe vel ab aliqua poteÅ¿tate de plebe aliquare per feudum & veÅ¿titus, Lib 2. feudall. tit. 10
is Capitane us
appellatur qui proprie ValvaÅ¿or. majores olim appellabantur, and of the queÅ¿tion ariÅ¿ing concerning theÅ¿e Baronies, the Monarch of the Realme or the Iudges, for that thoÅ¿e Barons are immediate Ã Rege in feudali, as for others they be Barons ex Å¿imilitudine, and therfore thoÅ¿e which in the Å¿aid lawes feudall are called ValvaÅ¿ores & ValvaÅ¿ini, for the words are theÅ¿e,Bract. lib. 1. cap. 8.
Qui vero a Capitaneis antiquitus beneficium tenent ValvaÅ¿ores Å¿unt, Qui autem a valvaÅ¿orib s feudum quod a Capitaneis habebatur, Å¿imiliter acceperint ValvaÅ¿ini, id eÅ¿t, valicas minores appellantur, The vÅ¿e of this diviÅ¿ion within England, hath beene in no other manner then this, The Valv. majores may be vnderÅ¿tood to be our Barons and Peeres for in Å¿uch manner the Interpreters of the law feudall have expreÅ¿Å¿ed the Å¿ame. The Å¿econd Å¿ort is the Valv. proprie of which degree Bracton alÅ¿o Å¿peaketh: Å¿unt & alij qui dicuntur ValvaÅ¿ores magni dignitat. ValvaÅ¿or melus dici poterit quia vas Å¿ortitum ad valetudinem. Howbeit the Civilians doe give another Etimologie in this manner,
ValvaÅ¿or. quaÅ¿i ad valvas Å¿tantes, Shand Lexico in verb va â¢ ve Pet. Greg. lib. 6. ca. 11.13 E. 3. Chal 115.
id eÅ¿t, tanquam ad valvas tentorij dum Å¿unt in bello excubantes ad quamlibet injuriam propulÅ¿andam; And of theÅ¿e valvaÅ¿i, which are properly the ValvaÅ¿i indeed, mention is made 13. E. 3. For they may be impannelled in a Iury among the Kinghts where a Baron is party. The third Å¿ort called ValvaÅ¿ini inÅ¿pecial name we have not in vÅ¿e, NevertheleÅ¿Å¿e they are in nature the Å¿ame that we call Lords and proprietors of Mannors, who alÅ¿o in reÅ¿pect of their Tenants were oftentimes in antient remembrances called Barons, but (abuÅ¿ive) and their Courts, Court-Barons, for of theÅ¿e Glanvill Å¿peaketh,Glan lib. 8. cap. 10. fol 64.
Praeterea Record. habeant minores Cur. de his quae in eis facta Å¿unt, &c. hence it is that theÅ¿e divers degrees have beene obÅ¿erved in forraigne Countries; By the French ConÅ¿titution it is ordained, that Si quis aut Vicecom. aut Baro voluerit fieri comes, neceÅ¿Å¿ariuÌ ducuÌt eum habere in Å¿ua ditione. 4. Baronias & tres caÅ¿tella. quaruÌ quaelibet habeat Å¿altem 10.Pet. Ger. in lib. 6. cap 9. Ex edito regis gall. 17. Angl. 1579
Nobiles Å¿ibi Å¿ubdit os qui eum comitari poÅ¿Å¿unt. Again, in
tit. comit. nullus tranÅ¿eat niÅ¿i habeat 2. Baroneas, & 3. CaÅ¿tellaneas aut Å¿altem, i. Baroniam & 6. CaÅ¿tellaneas vnitas & nomine feudi PoÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿at & inveÅ¿titas a rege Å¿ub uno titulo. Jac Mercant. Fland. 16. cap 1 de AloÅ¿to. In Flanders which was an Earldome of regall conÅ¿titution there was in auntient time an Earledome the Ea. whereof was intituled Comes AleÅ¿tanus the Earle of ElÅ¿ton, who although his juriÅ¿diction was particular to himÅ¿elfe from the Emperour, yet had he under him five Barons, the memory of which doth remaine; It hath beene heretofore a common received opinion, that every Earldome in times paÅ¿T had under it ten Barons, and every Baron Å¿even Knights fees holden of him, and Å¿ome are of opinion, that thoÅ¿e which had foureteene Knights fees were uÅ¿ually Barons, but of that more hereafter.

It reÅ¿teth now for the more explanation of the uÅ¿e of the name Baron, that wee call to remembrance that which is before Å¿poken, that the CuÅ¿tome of our Countrey is, that if a Baron be created an Earle; the eldeÅ¿t Å¿on
of the Å¿aid Earle, in the life of his l'ather, taketh upon him the title of the Barony, although he want the priviledges belonging to a Baron. LaÅ¿tly, that is not to be omitted, that by the generall name of the Barons of the Realme, wee doe underÅ¿tand the whole body of the Nobility, and hence it is that the civill warre concerning the liberties granted in the great Charter, both in the time of King Iohn, and H. 3. proÅ¿ecuted by the whole Nobilitie Å¿ome few excepted, are called the Barons warres; Thus much of their antiquitie, &c.

Having before Å¿hewed the Å¿everall uÅ¿es of the word Baron, The true uÅ¿e of the name. we are now to adhere onely to the proper Å¿ignification thereof, whereby there is denoted to us an Honourable perÅ¿onage next under the Vicount, and therefore wee are to Å¿et forth a diviÅ¿ion.

Barons honourable are of three kindes,3. kinds of Barons. by Tenure, by Writ, by Creation or Patent, as for the Baron by preÅ¿cription they are all one with the
Barons by tenure, or thoÅ¿e who antiently, and time out of mind have been called to the Parliament by Writ, and otherwiÅ¿e none.

Barons by tenure are thoÅ¿e which doe any honour,Barons by tenure 2. kinds. &c. as the head of their Barony, per Baroniam, which is called Graund Serjeanty; TheÅ¿e are of two Å¿orts Å¿pirituall and temporall.

The Barons Å¿pirituall per Tenure, Spirituall. are and were thoÅ¿e EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall perÅ¿ons, which held the principall part of their Å¿pirituall living per Baron. and Å¿uch were alÅ¿o of two kinds; firÅ¿t, the ArchbiÅ¿hops and BiÅ¿hops of this Realme, who doe hold the principall part of their temporalties per Baron. Secondly, Å¿uch Abbots, Priors, &c. which were extinguiÅ¿hed by comming to the Crowne by the Statute.

Barons temporall are Å¿uch as hold the chiefeÅ¿t part of their poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions,Temporal. as Å¿ome honour, CaÅ¿tle, &c. per Bar. of the Crowne, all which honourable Barons of holding their Baronies of the Crown were in antient time in reÅ¿pect of theÅ¿e their tenures called by the Monarch of this Realme to aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t him
in counÅ¿ell in Parliament.
But firÅ¿t it Å¿hall be requiÅ¿ite to prove every part of the diviÅ¿ion, namely of Barons by tenure, and firÅ¿t of Å¿pirituall.

It is evident, that the ArchbiÅ¿hops and BiÅ¿hops of the Realme in the Saxon dayes, as well during the time that it was divided into divers kingdomes, as alÅ¿o after the uniting of them into one Monarchy were called to the Parliament, not Å¿o much in reÅ¿pect of their tenure (for it was then by Frankalmoigne) but eÅ¿pecially for that lawes are then moÅ¿t commendable, when they are grounded upon the law of God,HiÅ¿t. Inguelf. Ab. de Croland. in Å¿ubÅ¿crip. Chartre Bertofli regis, fol. 490 ibid. 492. and therefore our wiÅ¿e AnceÅ¿tours called to their generall CounÅ¿ell or Wittenaymot or Court of wiÅ¿e men, as they called it thoÅ¿e principall perÅ¿ons of their Clergie, which by their profeÅ¿Å¿ion, &c. might adviÅ¿e them to frame their lives anÅ¿werably, &c.

NevertheleÅ¿Å¿e, Å¿hortly after the Norman ConqueÅ¿t, the Conquerour altered tenures, being before Frankalm. not without Å¿ome complaint
and griefe of the Clergie of which Matth. Paris thus writeth An. 1070. which prove that BiÅ¿hops then held per Baroniam. Matt. Paris, fol 6.

In the ConÅ¿titution held at Clarindon tempore, H. 2. Anno 1164. which conÅ¿titutions certaine recapitulations of the prerogative of the King and his people then Å¿ought to be infringed by the Pope and his Clergie,Called the AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿. of ClarindoÌ in old Writers. it is thus expreÅ¿Å¿ed in the 11. Article, ArchiepiÅ¿copi & EpiÅ¿copi, & univerÅ¿a perÅ¿ona regni qui de rege ten' in Cap. habeat poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion. Å¿uas de Rege Å¿icut Baroniam, & inde reÅ¿pondeant JuÅ¿ticiarijs, &c. Regis & faciant omnes conÅ¿uet. regias, & Å¿icut caeteri Barones debeant intereÅ¿Å¿e judicijs curiae Regis cum Baronibus quouÅ¿que. perveniatur ad diminutionem membrorum vel mortem.
10. E. 4.6. De Rot. ParliameÌt. 11. R. 2. an no 9 in turr. London. Here we Å¿ee the preÅ¿ence of the BiÅ¿hops in the Parliament in reÅ¿pect of their Baronies, QuouÅ¿
que perveniatur ad diminutionem, &c. For ever unto our times when queÅ¿tion is had of any attainder of any Peere in Parliament, they depart the higher houÅ¿e, and make their procurators, for by the Decrees of the
Church, they may not be judges of life and death.

Of the Baronies of BiÅ¿hops,Lib 9. fol. 66. and of their homage for the Å¿ame; Thus writeth Glanvill, who tempore R. 1. was chiefe JuÅ¿tice, EpiÅ¿copi vero conÅ¿ecrati homagium facere non Å¿olent Domino regi etiam de Baronijs Å¿uis Å¿ed fidelitat. cum jurament. interpoÅ¿it. ipÅ¿i praeÅ¿tare Å¿olent; Elect. vero in epiÅ¿copos ante conÅ¿ecraetioneÌ Å¿uam homag. Å¿ua facere Å¿olent. Of theÅ¿e alÅ¿o Bracton Å¿aith, St autem terra data fuit EccleÅ¿iat. Cathedral. vel conventurae non jacebit aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿a utrum quamvis in habitam, &c. EleemoÅ¿inam. Of the which hee reciteth a Judgement, P. 15. H. 3. which was given in a Writ of Errour upon a Judgement in Eire betweene the Prior of Lewes & Gilb. de Aquila, Bract lib 4. cap. 2.287. and he yeeldeth the reaÅ¿on thereof.

Againe,Bract. lib. 5. cap. 23. fol. 4.27. he in another place, Å¿earching out the reaÅ¿on why the certificate Excommunicat. Å¿piritualium, any Å¿pirituall Judge other then the ArchbiÅ¿hops and BiÅ¿hops of this Realme is not by any Law to be admitted, hee yeeldeth this reaÅ¿on Å¿o, that none of
thoÅ¿e other Å¿pirituall Judges are compellable to admit the action as are the the ArchbiÅ¿hops and BiÅ¿hops, Quia rex in epiÅ¿copis coercionem habet propter Baroniam, Meaning thereby that upon their contempt the King doth Å¿eaze their temporaltie. LikewiÅ¿e, about 46. E. 3. the BiÅ¿hop of ChicheÅ¿ter LeaÅ¿ed for life a Mannor parcell of his B â¢ rony with licence of the King,46. E. 3. forf. 8. this alienation was a forfeiture becauÅ¿e parcell of his Barony.

Many more authorities might be cited out of Records and bookes of Law,13. E. 3. Chal. 115. enqueÅ¿t. 43.29. E. 3.42. in regard whereof they have in antient time been named Peeres of the Realme, and have enjoyed other the priviledges that Peeres doe the triall by Peeres (onely in matters of TreaÅ¿on or miÅ¿priÅ¿ion, &c. excepted) wherof Stamford giveth the reaÅ¿on, Non ratione Nobilitatis Å¿ed ratione officij. 39. E. 3.30. 31. E. 3.94. 21. E. 4 77 27. H. 8. 27. H. 8.
â¢ nquÅ¿t. 99. 2. Mar. 46. 35. H. 8. Triall. 142. Stan. 1536. 1. H. 4.13. H 8 11. Another reaÅ¿on why BiÅ¿hops are not tryed by Peeres as other Peeres, becauÅ¿e they cannot paÅ¿Å¿e upon the life of any man, being thereunto forbidden by &c. and therefore the Peeres cannot trie them, for that this kind of
triall Å¿hould be mutuall if the offence give occaÅ¿ion, inÅ¿omuch that their cenÅ¿ure is upon their honour without oath, &c.

The like of thoÅ¿e Abbotts,21. E. 3.88 36. H. 6. 7. H. 6.108. 7. H. 4.2. 26. H. 8.7. 21. E. 3. n. 50. Priors, &c. which held Å¿ome part of their land per Bar. who were alÅ¿o called Peeres of the Realme, therefore no Capias againÅ¿t them, and therfore Å¿ome of them that held not per Bar. being Å¿ummoned to the Parliament upon their petition were diÅ¿charged, whereof there are Å¿ome preÅ¿idents extant.

The Abbot of Saint Iames neere North â¢ mpton, in 12. E. 3. was Å¿ummoned to the Parliament, which was the Å¿ame yeere holden at Yorke, who becauÅ¿e neither he nor his predeceÅ¿Å¿ors were Å¿ummoned, and becauÅ¿e he held onely by Frankalm. hee by his Procurator exhibited his petition to the Lord Chancellour a monument wherof I have Å¿een in this maÌner, Abbas Sancti Iacobi North, Irrotul. de novo in Cancell. dom. Regis inter citand. ad Parliamentum & non tent per Baroniam nec de rege in Capite Å¿ed tantum in
pura, Out of the RegiÅ¿ter booke of St. Iames of Northampton.
&c. EleemoÅ¿ina & nec ipe nec predeceÅ¿Å¿or. Å¿ui unquam in Cancellaria irrotulat. fuerunt nec ad Parliamentum cita. huc vÅ¿
que unde idem Abbas petit remedium. Ad cujus billam execut. Dominus Cancellar. cum Å¿uo ConÅ¿ilio de Cancell. ordinavit quod nomen praedict. Abbatis a regiÅ¿tro Cancel. deleretur & ita pluribus circumÅ¿pect. idem Abbas eÅ¿t abÅ¿olutus; facta eÅ¿t haec excuÅ¿atio per viÅ¿um Domini Iohannis de Oth. EpiÅ¿copi Elien. Cancil. domini regis, domini Willielmi Dirmins tunc cust. rotulorum & al'.

A like Petition was made by the Abbot of LeiceÅ¿ter unto K.E. 3. and thereupon obtained a Writ of diÅ¿charge in this forme;Ex. rot. Patent. 26. E. 3. pars. 1. M. 22. in turri London. Edwardus Dei gratia &c. Salut. Å¿upplicavit nobis dilect. nobis in ChriÅ¿to Abbas de LeyceÅ¿t. in Abbatia Å¿ua predict per Robert. Fits, Roberti de Mellent dudum Com. Leyc. fundata fuiÅ¿Å¿et in puraÌ eleemoÅ¿inam, & advocat.Å¿ibi preornat. ad manus Domini Hen. quondam regiae Angl. proavi nostri per forisfacturam, Simon. de Monte forte tunc Com. Leyc. & proin ejuÅ¿dem darent, idem
que Abbas alij

Now let us deÅ¿cend to the other authorities Sir Ralph Everdon Knight,48. In the Parliament 23. H. 6. there was a controuerÅ¿ie between W. E. of Arundell, Inter. rot. Parliamen, 27. H. 6. and Tho. H. 6. concerning the Å¿ame in the behalfe of Iohn E. of Arundell decided; his AnceÅ¿tors they certified, firÅ¿t, that the controverÅ¿ie was never matter of Parliament 2. that the Å¿aid act wherby it was ordained that the Å¿aid Iohn Å¿hould have his Å¿eat in the Kings preÅ¿ence a â¢ well in Parliament as elÅ¿-where as E. of Arundell there was no mention made of his heires but of himÅ¿elfe. 3. That to the caÅ¿tle, &c. of Arundell the name, &c. of Earle then was, and time out of mind had beene vnited and annexed, and by reaÅ¿on thereof the Å¿aide E. did hold that name and not by creation, all which being Å¿o certified it was enacted that the Å¿aid W. E. of Arundell Å¿hould retaine his prehemience by reaÅ¿on of the eaÅ¿tle as worÅ¿hipfully (for Å¿o are the words of the act) as any of the E. of Ar. above the E. of Devon, &c. and an Earldome by tenure, in regard of which the Earles thereof have had their place in Parliament, from whence may be deduced that the like may be obÅ¿erved of Baronies by tenure as of this E. by tenure I would wiÅ¿h thoÅ¿e that denye Baronies by tenure to conÅ¿ider the Å¿tatute of WeÅ¿t. 2. cap 42. where the Fees of the E. div.head: If a Baron by tenure grant the hononr holden by Barony. whether Å¿hall Å¿uch grantee have the Å¿aid dignitie or otherwiÅ¿e?
div.p: Argument ex parte neg. THey which deny Baronies by tenure doe vÅ¿e this as their principall reaÅ¿on, firÅ¿t, if there be any, then the Grantee of them muÅ¿t hold by the Å¿ame tenure as their Feoffer, 10.2. ca 1. Qu. â¢ mp. terrar. but that was per Baroniam: the refore. And if Å¿uch Grant bee made to perÅ¿ons ignoble, they then Å¿hould bee Noble which were abÅ¿ured.Ratio 1.
Secondly, it is very evident that many antient Mannors, which in antient time were holden per Baron. are now in the tenures of meane Gentlemen, who may not dare to challenge it.
Thirdly, Å¿ome antient Barons are which have Å¿old thoÅ¿e CaÅ¿tles, &c. and yet retaine their dignitie, and have been, and are Å¿ummoned to Parliament notwithÅ¿tanding.DiÅ¿tinctions conÅ¿iderable.

For the better anÅ¿er, it Å¿hall bee convenient to exhibit certaine neceÅ¿Å¿ary
diÅ¿tinctions and thence to draw infallible diÅ¿tinctions, and then Authorities and PreÅ¿idents.

FirÅ¿t therefore if a Baron by tenure doe aliene the Å¿ame,DiÅ¿tinct 1 either he doth it without licence, or elÅ¿e with licence obtained. If without Licence,The concluÅ¿ion. then the ConcluÅ¿ion is certaine that it is forfeited, and to be Å¿eized to the King, and the Dignity extinguiÅ¿hed in the Crown from whence it was derived.

The reaÅ¿on is out of Bracton, becauÅ¿e Baronies are the Å¿trength of the Kingdome, and if they Å¿hould be aliened without conÅ¿ent of the Soveriagne, baÅ¿e perÅ¿ons innobled without deÅ¿ert, &c. for where the thing Å¿o aliened is an Honour, it differeth much from the ordinary tenure in Cap. whereof if the Tenant make alienation without licence,50. E. 3 c. 10. he is onely to make a fine by the Statute. For authoritie. Glanvill Å¿aith,Mag. Char. cap 31. Glanv. l. 7. cap. 1.
Notandum eÅ¿t quod nec EpiÅ¿copus, nec Abbas quia corum Baroniae Å¿unt de EleemoÅ¿ina Regis non poÅ¿Å¿unt de Dominicis Å¿uis aliquam partem dare ad remanenciam Å¿ine aÅ¿Å¿enÅ¿u, & conÅ¿enÅ¿u Domini Regis.

In 20. E. 3. certaine land being parcell of the Baronie of Brenbur was aliened by W.de Bruce, 20. AÅ¿Å¿. 1 8 20 E. 3. AÅ¿Å¿. 122. & 224. the Baron thereof without licence, and in the argument of a CaÅ¿e concerning the Å¿ame, Greene Å¿aid that parcell of a Baronie, &c. held in chiefe, cannot bee aliened without his Licence. Againe, 46. E. 3. it was found by Office, that W. BiÅ¿hop of CheÅ¿ter had LeaÅ¿ed for life to Io. PeÅ¿ton a Mannor,46. E. 3. Forf. 18. parcell of the Baronie without Licence, and reÅ¿olved that it was forfeited, but by mediation of the Å¿aid CounÅ¿ell, the BiÅ¿hop Å¿ubmitted and made a fine, and Å¿everall Scire faec. iÅ¿Å¿ued againÅ¿t the perceptors of the profits to anÅ¿wer the King.DiÅ¿tinct. 2. Thus much of Alienation without Licence.
But of the other part, if a Baron by tenure doth aliene by Licence wee muÅ¿t diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h, for it is either made for the continuance of his Barony, &c. or elÅ¿e for Å¿ome other conÅ¿ideration.

That if any Å¿uch Alienation be made for the continuance of the Barony in the name, then have the iÅ¿Å¿ue male with the CaÅ¿tle, &c. retained the Dignitie
of a Baron, and hereof have the Heires generall, or next Heires females beene excluded; And for proofe of this aÅ¿Å¿ertion many antient PreÅ¿idents may be produced, Å¿eeing they have happened almoÅ¿t in every age for three hundred yeares Å¿pace, of which Å¿ome certaine doe enÅ¿ue.

Lo. de la Ware Knight, although Iohn Griffeth was heire of the whole blood.

Eliz. was Å¿eized in fee of the Baronies of Longden and Haywood, and of, and in the Mannors of BewdÅ¿ert Longden, &c. and being Å¿o Å¿eized by fine, 1. Moreover thirdly,3. ConcluÅ¿ion. if a Baron by tenure doth Aliene by Licence to a meere Å¿tranger upon conÅ¿ideration, or, &c. if Å¿uch Alience be nobly deÅ¿cended in Å¿uch caÅ¿es, after Å¿uch alienations, Å¿uch Alience hath borne the name and dignitie of a Baron, in reÅ¿pect of Å¿uch Barony Å¿o aliened; And if he had no Dignity before, hee in reÅ¿pect of that hath beene Å¿ummoned to

NevertheleÅ¿Å¿e the Å¿aid Earle, and after him the Å¿aid Hen. Percy his Son were Barons of the Å¿aid Honour by the Å¿aid aÅ¿Å¿urance, and Sir William Melton Knight, Couzen and next Heire of the Å¿aid CounteÅ¿Å¿e never had the Å¿aid Armes.

AmongÅ¿t the Parents in the Tower,Chart patent. in 41. H 3.
Anno 41. H. 3. it appearth that one Herward de MariÅ¿co and Rameta his
wife did grant unto Simon de Mountfort, then Earle of LeyceÅ¿ter, the Barony of Elinden in the County of Northampton, which deÅ¿cended to the Å¿aid Rameta from John de VeÅ¿count, which Graunt Å¿eemeth to be with Licence, for that the Å¿aid King doth by his Patent confirme the Å¿ame, and further gave to the Å¿aid Earle and his Heires divers priviledges there.

AlÅ¿o,Exchange of a Barony. this antient Charter following concerning the exchange of a Barony with the King, is worthy memory, which is, K. Iohn ao. 7. granted unto Robert de Newbergh Fordington, for the honour of BurÅ¿tocke in exchange, and granted that it Å¿hould be the head, and the chiefe of the BaronÅ¿hip, as BurÅ¿tock was aforetime, and that all Knights and others Å¿hould attend upon him, and his lands in Fordington as chiefe of his BaronÅ¿hip, as they aforetime were attendant upon Robert BurÅ¿tock.
By theÅ¿e PreÅ¿idents appeareth, that Barony by tenure is annexa feodo. So that the former queÅ¿tions are fully Å¿atisfied and anÅ¿wered (viz.)

list.item: 1. That by alienation without Licence, the Barony is ferfeited.
2. The heires Males have enjoyed them, and the Females excluded.
3. That the Alience of Å¿uch a Barony (nobly deÅ¿cended) is Baron.

div.p: But if Å¿uch alienation with Licence be made to any perÅ¿on ignoble,Nora. 1. though the burden of the tenure doth remaine on him for the K. beÅ¿t advantage, yet he may not take upon him the Dignitie without the Kings Å¿peciall favour upon his merit.

Upon conÅ¿ideration therefore of theÅ¿e aÅ¿Å¿ertions all the former objections are anÅ¿wered, and as touching the firÅ¿t, it is anÅ¿wered by that which is laÅ¿t Å¿pecified, that an ignoble Alience may challenge nothing as a Baron by tenure.

In 11. H. 4.2.6. in a CaÅ¿e concerning a DiÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿e, it is agreed that a Baron,11. H. 4.2.6. &c. are not contributary for Å¿uch lands parcell of their Barony, but for other lands they are; but there is queÅ¿tion made, if one which is not Baron purchaÅ¿e a Barony, whether hee Å¿hall be diÅ¿charged, which was not
worthy the queÅ¿tioning, if Å¿uch a purchaÅ¿er challenge by reaÅ¿on of his purchaÅ¿e place in Parliament; For as land holden by villein Å¿ervice, doth not make the owner a villein which doth purchaÅ¿e the Å¿ame, although by tenure he muÅ¿t doe villein Å¿ervice; So land holden by Baron Å¿ervice doth not make the ignoble noble, though the charge of Å¿uch tenure lay upon him. Yet if the King will give to any man ignoble in recompence of Å¿ervice any CaÅ¿tle, &c. to be holden per Baroniam, hee is forthwith noble, becauÅ¿e hee draweth this Nobilitie from the fountaine without other Creation.
But a queÅ¿tion by the way what yeerely revenue is Å¿ufficient for a Baron.Qu.

DiverÅ¿itie of times hath brought forth divers determinations as touching the French conÅ¿titution,R. there is an old Pamphlet wherein are theÅ¿e words; Summon. debeant omnes Comit. & Barones, & eorum pares (viz) qui habent terras & reddit. ad valentiam Commitat. vel Baron. integre, Modus tenend. parliament. viz. 20. feod. Milit. quolibet feod. comput.
ad 12. librat. quae faciunt librat. vel ad valenc. 13. feod. Milit. & 3. part. Vnius feodi Milit. quolibet feod. computand. ad 20. librat. quae faciunt in toto 400. mercas, & nulli minores laici Å¿ommon. debeant ad Parliament. ratione tenur. niÅ¿i eorum praeÅ¿entia alijs de cauÅ¿is fuerit neceÅ¿Å¿e (cap. du Laicis.) The revenew of a Baron. Camden in Britann. Others have eÅ¿teemed it to be foureteene Knights Fees, but that doth reÅ¿t wholly in the pleaÅ¿ure of the King to judge.
