The bookes of law doe make difference herein betweene Duke, MarqueÅ¿Å¿e,8. H. 6.10. 30 H. 8.30 Earle, ViÅ¿count, &c. which are allowed names of Dignitie and the Baron, for they affirme that Å¿uch Baron needeth not to be named Lord or Baron by his Writ, but the Duke, MarqueÅ¿Å¿e, Earle or ViÅ¿count, ought to be named by their Names or Dignities; NevertheleÅ¿Å¿e I doe take theÅ¿e bookes to be underÅ¿tood of the Barony by tenure, or Barons by Writ onely, for the title of a Baron by Patent in his Letters Patents under Seale adorned, and named by the name of Status, gradus & dignitas, and therefore is requiÅ¿ite to be named, and Å¿uch dignities are a parcell of the name of the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿or, as well as the Title and Stile of Duke, MarqueÅ¿Å¿e, Earle, ViÅ¿count, &c.

And although there may be conceived this difference laÅ¿t mentioned betweene the Baron by tenure or Writ, and the Baron by Patent, yet they being
all members of the higher houÅ¿e of the Parliament, they are thereby equally made Noble, Honourable, and Peeres of the Realme, as they are Barons onely, without any other diÅ¿tinction that I have obÅ¿erved. And thus much concerning the three degrees of Barons within this Realme may Å¿uffice to be Å¿aid in generall upon this occaÅ¿ion, for the better underÅ¿tanding and reÅ¿olution of the controverÅ¿ie in hand.The priviledge of Barons.

There reÅ¿teth laÅ¿t of all in this TreatiÅ¿e of Baronage that I would expreÅ¿Å¿e Å¿ome certaine of the Å¿undry priviledges that the Lawes doe allow unto Barons, and the Nobilitie of the Realm ingenerall, in regard of that favour, which all good policy in every wel-governed Common-wealth doth beÅ¿tow and yeeld to the Noble and Honourable, wherein I Å¿hall content my Å¿elfe onely with certaine of thoÅ¿e priviledges which I find mentioned in the Lawes of this Realme, purpoÅ¿ely omitting Å¿uch as either the Civill, Common, or the lawes of forraigne Countries doe afford, referring them
to a fit place in an intended TreatiÅ¿e of Nobilitie.Priviledge.

FirÅ¿t therefore it is a priviledge that the Peeres and Nobilitie of the Parliament doe enjoy, namely to bee tried in the caÅ¿es of TreaÅ¿on, Felony, Mag. Char. 29 10. E. 4.6.20. H. 6. cap. 9 and Å¿uch like by their Peeres.

The antiquitie and originall of this kind of triall hath (as Å¿ome men doe thinke) his ground from the Statute of Magna Charta, cap. 29. beginning that Nullus liber homo, in theÅ¿e words, Nec Å¿uper eum ibimus, nec Å¿uper eum mittimus niÅ¿i per legale judicium Parium Å¿uorum. But I take it to be more antient,Triall by Peeres Where allowable De conÅ¿uet. feudorum. as brought into this Realme with the Conquerour, being anÅ¿werable to the Norman and French lawes, and agreeable with the cuÅ¿tomes Å¿everall, where almoÅ¿t all controverÅ¿ies ariÅ¿ing betweene the Soveraigne and his Peeres are tried, per judicium Parium Å¿uorum.

This Triall in antient time was very oft had in Parliament as may bee collected by the Statute of 15. E. 3. cap. 6.15. E. 3. cap. 6. 1. H. 4.1. 13 H. 8.11 But nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e the Å¿ame may as well be performed by CommiÅ¿Å¿ion
under the Lord Steward of Eng. the forme, manner, and Solemnitie wherof is expreÅ¿Å¿ed in the bookes of Law.
This priviledge hath Å¿ome reÅ¿traint, as well in regard of the perÅ¿on,The reÅ¿traint of the praviledge. as in the manner of proceedings. As touching the perÅ¿on.

FirÅ¿t, the ArchbiÅ¿hops of this Realme, although they bee Lords of the Parliament, if they bee impeached of Å¿uch aÅ¿Å¿ent as aforeÅ¿aid, Å¿hall not be tried by the Peeres of this Realme, but by a Jury of other Å¿ubÅ¿tantiall perÅ¿ons upon their oathes, the reaÅ¿on thereof (as I can conceive) as before remembred, 27. H. 8. Br. InqueÅ¿t. 100 Triall 142. Fine 2. Stamf. 153 namely for as much as the ArchbiÅ¿hops and BiÅ¿hops cannot paÅ¿Å¿e in the like caÅ¿es upon the tryall of any other of the Peeres, for that they are prohibited by the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall lawes to bee judges of life and blood, reaÅ¿on would that the other Peeres Å¿hould not trie them: for this triall Å¿hould be mutuall foraÅ¿much as it is performed upon their Honour without any oath taken.

Secondly, as touching the perÅ¿on,38. H. 6. Br. TreaÅ¿on. none but Lords of the Laytie being
Lords of the Parliament, 38. H 8. CaÅ¿e Leo. Grey en le â¢ Con. Å¿hall have this kind of Triall. And therefore hereout are excluded the eldeÅ¿t Sonne and heire apparent of a Duke, in the life of his Father, though he be called Earle & beare that title, LikewiÅ¿e, the eldeÅ¿t Sonne and Heire apparent of an Earle, though he be onely a Lord, or Baron, or beare Å¿uch Title.

ThoÅ¿e that are Barons, and of the Nobility of Ireland, 19 & 20. Eliz 36.6. if upon the like offence committed in Engl. if they chance to be apprehended in Engl. they Å¿hall not be tried herein by their Peeres, For the Lords of the Parliament of England are not their Peeres, but the Lords of the Parliament in Ireland.
And thus much concerning the ReÅ¿traints of the Å¿aid priviledges in reÅ¿pect of the perÅ¿on.

As touching the manner of Proceeding the Nobilitie of this Realme doe injoy the priviledge of triall by their Peeres in CourÅ¿e of Inditement onely,33. H 8. Br. Iurors, 48. Triall. 142. 10 E. 3.6. Stam 152. which is a kind of proceeding ex officio between the Qu. highneÅ¿Å¿e and them, But in any caÅ¿e of Appeale of felony,
which is in the Å¿uite of the Å¿ubject, they Å¿hall not have the Å¿ame, but Å¿hall be tried by a Jury of 12. men upon their oathes. And thus much concerning this priviledge at this place, and upon this occaÅ¿ion may Å¿uffice.

LikewiÅ¿e this priviledge the Nobility of this Realme doe enjoy, PrivilegiuÌ Å¿ecundum. 48. E. 3.30 48. AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿. 6. 35 H. 6.46 22. H. 8.22 Reg. 1 79. 15 Eliz. 315. That they are not Å¿o to be inpannelled in any Jury or inqueÅ¿t, to make triall or inquiry upon their corporall oathes between partie and partie, And if they be impannelled contrary thereunto, they may have a writ out of the Chancery repeating this priviledge directed to the IuÅ¿tices, before whom Å¿uch noble perÅ¿onages are impannelled, commanding them to diÅ¿Å¿miÅ¿Å¿e him or them, that were Å¿o impannelled out of the Å¿aid Pannell.

This priviledge hath reÅ¿traint in two caÅ¿es,ReÅ¿traint. 1. firÅ¿t if he inquire concerning the King and CoÌmon-wealth in any neceÅ¿Å¿ary and important Decrees, as buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e of this Realme, then this priviledge is not allowed, nor taketh place. And therefore divers Barons of the Marches of Wales, were impaÌnelled
before the BiÅ¿hop of Ely, and other CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners of Oyer and Terminer, to inquire of notable outrage committed by Gilbe â¢ t de Clare, Earle of GlouceÅ¿ter, againÅ¿t Humfrey de Bohun, Earle of Pereford and EÅ¿Å¿ex, and his Å¿uits in Wales in the 20. yeere of E. 1. where Iohn de HaÅ¿tings, Edmond de Mortimer, Theobald de Verdune, and other of the Barons of the March â¢ s of Wales challenged their priviledges aforeÅ¿aid, and much inÅ¿iÅ¿ted upon the Å¿ame, but it was afterwards anÅ¿wered by the Court, as by the words of the appeareth, 20 E. 1. Rel. 14. Camera. Scar. Eo quod res iÅ¿t a dominum Regem & coronam & dignitatem Å¿uos tangit deinde fuit ex parte domini Regis IohaÌnt HaÅ¿tings. & omnibus alijs magnat. Å¿upranominat. quod pro Å¿tatu & jure regnt, & Pro conÅ¿ervatione dignitatis Coronae, & pacis Å¿uae opponant manum, ad librum, ad faciend. &c. quod eis ex parte Domini Regis injungentur, &c. The Barons aforeÅ¿aid nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e did perÅ¿iÅ¿t in their Challenge, and in the end both the Å¿aid Earle, betweene whom the Å¿aid outrage had heene perpetrated,
Å¿ubmitted themÅ¿elves to the Kings grace, and made their Fines.

Secondly,ReÅ¿traint 2 this priviledge hath no place in caÅ¿e of neceÅ¿Å¿itie, where the truth can no otherwiÅ¿e come to light, for the Writ is,RegiÅ¿t. 179.
Quia Barones in AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿Å¿is jurat. &c. poni non conÅ¿uÃªrunt. ut dicunt niÅ¿i eorum Sacrament. adeo Å¿it neceÅ¿Å¿arium quod Å¿ine illis verit as in qua non poÅ¿Å¿it, tibi praecepimus, &c.

In many CaÅ¿es the ProteÅ¿tation of honour Å¿hall Å¿atisfie in Noblemen, Privileg. 3. Bract. l. 5. cap. 9. fol. 352.8.3.1. H. 4.1.13 H. 8.1 3 H. 6.48. Cooke 6.53 as in triall of their Peeres, they proceed upon their honour, not upon their oath. And if a Nobleman on an action of debt upon an Accompt, in caÅ¿e where the Plaintife is to be examined upon oath, upon the Statute of 5. H. 4. cap. 8. it Å¿hall Å¿uffice to examine his Attorney, and not himÅ¿elfe upon his oath.

Yet if a Nobleman will give evidence to a Jury, reaÅ¿on would that he Å¿hould bee Å¿worne, for they are not bound to beleeve him upon Å¿uch proteÅ¿tation otherwiÅ¿e then they thinke in their conÅ¿cience to be conformable unto truth.

If a man doth receive a menace at the hand of a Nobleman,Privileg. whereupon he conceiveth feare of his Å¿afegard,35 H 6. Sub-paena 20 V. 14. E. 3. and prayes a Supplicavit in the Chan. directed unto the JuÅ¿tice of peace, or Sheriffe to take bond, &c. Å¿uch Writ which otherwiÅ¿e is ordinary, but the Lord Chancellour Å¿hall award a Sub-paena in Å¿tead thereof, and when he appeareth in Å¿tead of Å¿urety, he Å¿hall onely promiÅ¿e upon his Honour to keepe the peace, which the Law hath allowed in this point a Caution Å¿ufficient.

A nobleman is not to bee arreÅ¿ted by any Capias,
Privileg. 5. 21. E. 3.39. 43. E. 3.33. 8 R 2 7. H. 4 2. 11. H. 4.15 1. H. 5.14. 14. H. 6.2. 22 H. 6.226. 26. H 8.7. 14. Eliz 115. ReÅ¿taint. and therefore cannot be outlawed in any civill Action, but onely in Criminall.
And by the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on lyeth no Attachment againÅ¿t him, as it was ruled in Parliament, 14. Eliz. in the Lord Cromwells CaÅ¿e.

But if he make any notable contempt againÅ¿t the proceedings, of the Law, then ceaÅ¿eth this priviledge, for FruÅ¿tra legis auxilium invocat, qui in legem peccat. As if in a Writ de homine replegiando, hee will not permit the
Sheriffe to execute the Writ or EÅ¿Å¿oigne the party, or upon a ReÅ¿couÅ¿Å¿e a Capias hath this priviledge notwithÅ¿tanding.
So in caÅ¿es Criminall,27. H. 8.14 15. H. 7.1. a Capias and an Exigent may be awarded.

The like priviledges doth the Court of equitie allow in caÅ¿es of conÅ¿cience,Chanc. nomine Sub-paena. for the Lord Chancellour doth not award any Sub-paena, but Å¿endeth his Letters miÅ¿Å¿ive in lieu of other ordinary ProceÅ¿Å¿e.

In the proÅ¿ecution of any Action perÅ¿onall, Privil. 6. 14 E. 3.22. 15 E. 3.21 22 E. 3.9. 27. E. 38. 41. E 3.31 27 H. 8.22 the Plaintife may pray Jour de grace, but againÅ¿t a Peere of the Realme, it Å¿hall not be allowed, although it be allowable againÅ¿t other perÅ¿ons.

If any Lord Spirituall or Temporall be partie to any Action, Privileg. 7. 13. E 3. â¢â¢
Chal. 115. â¢ 22. H 8.22 Dyer. 107.3. & 4. Elize 24 9. & 10. Eliz. 26. there ought to be one Knight at the leaÅ¿t, to be impannelled in his Jury, with other the moÅ¿t Å¿ufficienteÅ¿t EÅ¿quires in the Countrey, otherwiÅ¿e he may challenge the Array, but if there bee no Knight in the County, the Pannell Å¿hal be made of the moÅ¿t Å¿ufficient VavaÅ¿ours and EÅ¿quires there inhabiting.

But if one bring an Action againÅ¿t another, and the Sh â¢ riffe impannell a Jury, where there is not any Knight,14. & 15. Eliz. 318. and before the Triall the Plaintife or Defendant is Created a Baron, or, &c. and hee doe challenge the Å¿aid Jury, Å¿uch challenge Å¿hall not bee allowed, for at the time of the enqueÅ¿t made, he was not Å¿o reputed, as in the CaÅ¿e of Reginald, late Earle of Kent may appeare.

If the King grant an Annuitie or Rent, to a then created Baron,Privileg 8. for the Å¿upport of his Degree,6. H. 6.2. which they call creation money, this is Å¿o annexed to the Dignitie, that by no manner of alienation it can be Å¿evered.

If the King upon Å¿uch Creation give land, &c. untill he Å¿hall bee advanced to Å¿ome other living, and upon Eviction to have the valew, if he be impleaded of this land by Scire facias, 21. E. 3.47 &c. hee Å¿hall have aid of the King.

If a Baron be partie to a Å¿uite,Privileg. 9. Pract. l. 5. fol 337. & 351. and would be eÅ¿Å¿oigned, hee that caÅ¿ts the eÅ¿Å¿oigne out, to put in Å¿ureties to prove the cauÅ¿e which is not uÅ¿uall in
caÅ¿e of common perÅ¿ons.

In all caÅ¿es where he is to be amerced his amerciament is not leÅ¿Å¿e then a hundred Å¿hil â¢ ings by the Statute o â¢
Magna Charta 14. and it was to be affirmed by hi â¢ Peeres. Privil. 10.16 E. 3
â¢ m. 14 38 E. 3 31 1. H. 6.7.9 H. 6 2 32. H. 6 30 19. E. 3.9.21. E 4 77 Fleta. lib. 2. But for that it were troubleÅ¿ome to aÅ¿Å¿emble Barons for Å¿o Å¿mall matter, Å¿uch amerciaments in time paÅ¿t have beene obtained by the Barons of the Exchequer, who were Å¿ometimes Barons of the Realme.

Whereas by the Statute 32. H. 8. no Å¿ubject might keepe in his family above foure Strangers borne, Privil. 11. Br. fol. 116 Co â¢ ke 8 39. Stat. 32 H. 8.16. Privil. 12 yet by a ProviÅ¿o every Baron may keepe Å¿ixe.

If a Lord of the Parliament having place and voyce there, Stat 1. E. 6. cap. 13. be convicted of Felony, wherein Clergie is allowed, upon requeÅ¿t, alleadging that hee is a Baron, &c. and clayming the benefit of his Clergie, although hee cannot reade without burning in the hand, loÅ¿Å¿e of Inheritance or corruption of blood, hee Å¿hall for the firÅ¿t time bee deemed a Clerke convict, and may have purgation.

AlÅ¿o,Privile. 13. whereas it is ordained that
the JuÅ¿tice of the Peace named of the Quorum, Å¿hall be reÅ¿ident in his Shire,Stat. 2. H 5 cap. 4. by a ProviÅ¿o, the Peeres of the Realme are exampted.

By the antient Lawes before William the Conquerors time,Lemb. perambul. de Kent. 21. Britt. cap. 29. Marlb. cap 10. every man above 12. yeeres Å¿hould be Å¿worne to the King, which we obÅ¿erve now in the veiw of Francke-pledge, Courtleete. But noble men, &c. are neither bound to attend the Leete nor take the oath.
If an Error be brought in Parliament upon a Iudgement in B. R. the upper houÅ¿e alone without the Commons,Postaat. 20. are to examine the errors.

In 11. H. 6.2. in a caÅ¿e concerning diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿e taken for expences and fees of the Knights of the Parliament.11. H 6.2. It was agreed that the Barons are not contributorie for Lands, parcell of the antient Barony, but for other lands: but there is a queÅ¿tion made whether the purchaÅ¿er of Å¿uch an antient Barony Å¿hould enjoy the Å¿aid priviledge, which queÅ¿tion was not worthy the queÅ¿tioning, for as lands holden by Villaines Å¿ervice doth not make the
free purchaÅ¿er a Villaine, though he be bound to doe Å¿uch Villaine Å¿ervice: Å¿o doth not Å¿uch PurchaÅ¿e ennoble him that purchaÅ¿eth.

By the Stat. of 5. Eliz. cap 1. all BurgeÅ¿Å¿es of Parliament Å¿hall take the oath of Å¿upremacie,Sta â¢ . 5 Eliz cap. 1. Å¿o Å¿hall Citizens and Barons of Cinqueports, But there is a ProviÅ¿o in that Stat. that foraÅ¿much as the Qu. is otherwiÅ¿e Å¿ufficiently aÅ¿Å¿ured of the faith, &c. of the temporall lawes; Therfore this act Å¿hall not compellany of, or above the degree of a Baron to take this oath, nor to incurre any penalty limited for the refuÅ¿all.

By the Stat. of 5. R. 2. cap. 12. the King defendeth the paÅ¿Å¿age of all manner of People in every Port,Stat. 5. R. 2. cap. 12.
&c. upon the Sea CoaÅ¿t upon paine of forfeiture of all their goods, except Lo. and other great men, and true and notable Merchants, and the Kings Å¿ouldiers and all others Å¿hall forfeit, &c. But becauÅ¿e the Statute is abrogated by 4. Iacobi, c. 2. I do not Å¿et this down for one of the priviledges at this day; But Philip Earle of Arundell, Son of
Thomas Duke of Norfolke, Cromptons IuriÅ¿d. 31. was taken upon the Sea paÅ¿Å¿ing into France about 30. Eliz. and was fined in the Starre chamber, becauÅ¿e he tooke not Å¿h â¢ pping at one of the Ports mentioned in that Statute.

In the Priviledge before mentioned of his Clergie, it Å¿hall be allowed him for breaking a houÅ¿e by day or night, for robbing upon the high-way, and in all other caÅ¿es excepted in the Stat. of 1. E. 6.12. Å¿aving in wilfull murder and poyÅ¿oning, But in all other caÅ¿es, wherein Clergie is taken away, he is in the Å¿ame degree with a common perÅ¿on, but the Court will not give him the benefit of this Statute, if he requireth not the Å¿ame. If a Lord doth confeÅ¿Å¿e his offence upon arraignment or abjure, or is outlawed for felony, in theÅ¿e caÅ¿es it Å¿eemeth he may have the benefit of this Statute, viz. his Clergie, for that by the Statute of 18. Eliz. cap. 81. hee nor any other need to make purgation,Stat. 18. Eliz. cap. 18. but Å¿hall bee forthwith delivered out of priÅ¿on by the JuÅ¿tice. Sed quaere Bolton 202. by the Imperiall conÅ¿titution,
Nobiles non torquentur in caÅ¿ibus, in quibus plebei torquentur nec Å¿uÅ¿penduntur, Å¿ed decapitantur. Which forme by favour of the Prince is allowed in England; IuriÅ¿d. Br. 48. Yet Thomas Fines, Lord Dacres, of the South. in the 37. H. 8. and the Lord Sturton 4. Mar. were hanged.

By the Staute of 1. Eliz. cap. 1. for uniformitie of Common prayer, 1. Eliz cap. 1. there is a proviÅ¿o, that the Baron Å¿hall bee tried per Pares, and not by any EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Courts, read the Statute at large.

At the Common law it was lawfull, for any to retaine as many Chaplains as he would, but by the Statute of 21. H. 8 13. a reÅ¿traint was made, viz. to every ArchbiÅ¿hop, and Duke, Å¿ixe Chaplains, with diÅ¿penÅ¿ation to keepe two Benefices with Cure, to every MarqueÅ¿Å¿e or Earle five, with the like priviledge; To the Lord Chancellour, every Baron and Knight of the Garter three, with the Å¿ame priviledge. If a BiÅ¿hop bee made an ArchbiÅ¿hop, or a Baron an Earle, yet can they have but Chaplains as ArchbiÅ¿hop
or Earle, becauÅ¿e though there be divers Dignities, yet the Å¿ervice is to be done, but to one perÅ¿on; Å¿o if he be removed from his Office, in this caÅ¿e he cannot be Non-reÅ¿ident without he procure a non obÅ¿tante.
So if a Baron retaine a Chaplaine, and before he is advanced, his Lord is attainted,Cooke rep. 4.117. Actons CaÅ¿e. as the Earle of WeÅ¿tmerland was, hee cannot accept a Å¿econd Benefice.
ThoÅ¿e that are firÅ¿t retained, Å¿hall onely have priviledge in caÅ¿e, &c.

By the Statute of 2. H. 5.8. that gives authoritie to the Sheriffe to raiÅ¿e PoÅ¿Å¿e Comitat. NevertheleÅ¿Å¿e, may he not command the perÅ¿on of a Nobleman to attend that Å¿ervice, but if the Sheriff upon a Å¿upplicavit againÅ¿t him, returne that he is Å¿o puiÅ¿Å¿ant that he dare not arreÅ¿t him, the Sheriffe Å¿hall be grievouÅ¿ly amerced for Å¿uch returne, for the Writ is to all ArchbiÅ¿hops, BiÅ¿hops, Dukes, Earles, &c. and to all liege men of the County to to be ayding to him, therefore by intendment none will reÅ¿iÅ¿t the execution.

The words of Charta de foreÅ¿t. cap. 11. are every ArchbiÅ¿hop, BiÅ¿hop, Earle, or Baron, comming to us at our commandment and paÅ¿Å¿ing by our forreÅ¿ts may take one beaÅ¿t or two by the view of the foreÅ¿ter if he be preÅ¿ent, or elÅ¿e he Å¿hall cauÅ¿e one to blow an horne that he Å¿eeme not to Å¿teale our Deare. In this Stat. though a Duke, MarqueÅ¿Å¿e, or ViÅ¿count, being Lord of the Parliament being commanded, &c. Å¿hall have the Å¿ame priviledge, Å¿o if the King Å¿end for him letters miÅ¿Å¿ive, MeÅ¿Å¿enger or Sergeant at arms, or by writ of Sub-paena, to appear in Chanc. they Å¿hall have the benefit of this Statute becauÅ¿e they came at the Kings commandement Å¿o in caÅ¿e of Scire facias out of the Chancery or D. R.

But if Å¿uch ProceÅ¿Å¿e goe out of the C. B. to appeare before the IuÅ¿tices or the Barons of the Exchequer he Å¿hall not have the benefit of the Statute, becauÅ¿e the Statute is Veniens ad nos, and in thoÅ¿e Courts they are, Quod coram nobis, &c. So of the Starre-chamber. AlÅ¿o Lords that come to viÅ¿it the new
King, though not Å¿ent for, Å¿hall have the priviledge: and Å¿o note this Statute is a Warrant dormant and is to be vnderÅ¿tood of their returning homeward Manwood, cap. 13. Crompton Iuris, Nota. D. 167. note the Statute doth give licence to kill or hunt in the Kings Parkes, though the Letter bee TranÅ¿iens per forreÅ¿tam noÅ¿tram. Note that in certaine CaÅ¿es the Law doth give priviledge to the Å¿onnes or brethren of Noblemen, though they bee not of that degree, Stat. 21. H. 8.13. &c. 7. E. 6. cap. 5.

div.head: Certaine CaÅ¿es wherein he hath no Priviledges.
div.p:
IF the King commit a Baron to priÅ¿on Durante bene placito, he cannot be diÅ¿charged by Bayle or mainpriÅ¿e, or by the common Writ De homine replegiando. And by the Å¿ame power it is if a noble perÅ¿on bee committed by the Kings Councell, for they are incorporated to his HighneÅ¿Å¿e, and doe command, as with the Kings mouth: and the Å¿ame law is, if a Nobleman be
committed to priÅ¿on by the abÅ¿olute Commandment of the Kings Judges, Å¿itting in their place of Judicature,Stam. lib 2. cap 18. fol. 72.
Stamf. lib. 2. cap. 18. fol. 72. as you have before, when the Prince himÅ¿elfe by the chiefe JuÅ¿tice Å¿itting in the Kings Bench, and was not bay leable. AlÅ¿o a Capias and an Exigent may be awarded upon an Indictment of a felony.

This Statute of Praemunire, cap. 1.16. R, 2. cap. 1. upon which Statute an Abbot which was Lord of the Parliament, being impleaded, did pray priviledge to appeare by attorney, Et per Curiam, could not for a CeÅ¿Å¿avit lyeth againÅ¿t him.
Upon contempt of Peeres a Capias may bee awarded, 1. H. 5. ult. 27. H. 8.22.

If he depart the Realme as EmbaÅ¿Å¿adour, &c. and returne not at the Kings commandement, the King may Å¿eize his lands and goods, Dyer 108.176. The Dutches of Suffolkes caÅ¿e, if he impriÅ¿on any man in his houÅ¿e, whereupon there is a writ De homine replegiando, if he convey him from the
Sheriffe the Court will award a Withernam to arreÅ¿t,11. H. 4.15 and impriÅ¿on him till he deliver the priÅ¿oner.
All Lords are compellable to take the oath mentioned in the Statute 3. Iacobi, and Å¿ee the Statute of 7. Iacobi, 3. Iac. ca. 4. 7 Ia. cap. 6. who hav eauthoritie to adminiÅ¿ter it unto them.

Being arraigned of felony in an Appeale, he Å¿hall not be tried by his Peeres, as in caÅ¿e of Inditement, in which caÅ¿e he may not challenge any of the Triers, either peremptorily or upon cauÅ¿es which is permitted to all other common perÅ¿ons.
The Iudgment is the vÅ¿uall Iudgement given againÅ¿t common perÅ¿ons, and though the King pardon all but the loÅ¿Å¿e of his head, that is of Å¿peciall grace not ex debito.
By Attainder the blood is corrupted and he and his poÅ¿terity made ignoble,Stam. lib. 3. cap. 34. and cannot be reÅ¿tored by the Kings pardon, but onely by authoritie of Parliament.

And note that Nobility is not a thing Å¿ubÅ¿tantiall, but meerely accidentall preÅ¿ent or abÅ¿ent without corruption
of his Å¿ubject, for experience Å¿hewes that honourable titles are reÅ¿trained by exorbitant crimes, when the nature in the meane while cannot be thruÅ¿t out with a forke, wherefore though we tearme extinguiÅ¿hment of Nobility in caÅ¿es of Attainder, yet this phraÅ¿e is not vÅ¿ed as though Nobility were eÅ¿Å¿entially in the homour of the blood more then any other hereditary faculty; But becauÅ¿e the right of inheritance which deÅ¿cends by communication of blood, is by that meanes determined, and alÅ¿o in regard of the deteÅ¿tation of the crime, it is called corruption of blood, 16. Eliz. Dyer 332. The Lord Charles Flowards caÅ¿e, if one be made a Knight by a forraign King, he is Å¿o to be Å¿tiled in all legall proceedings in this Realme, But if he be created by the Emperour an Earle, it is other wiÅ¿e, Coke 7.16.

If the King Create the Å¿on a Duke, &c. and the father dies, he within age Å¿hal be in ward, but if he had bin made a Knight in his f â¢â¢ hers life, he Å¿hould not be in ward, neither for the lands deÅ¿cended, nor marriage, Coke 74.
Drueries CaÅ¿e, though he be within age.

div.head: Nobilitie and Lords in reputation onely.
div.p: THere be other Lords in reputation and appellation, who nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e are not Iure, neither can they enjoy the priviledges of thoÅ¿e of the Nobilitie of the Parliament (viz.)

The Sonne and heire of a Duke, during the life of his father, is onely by curteÅ¿ie called an Earle, and the eldeÅ¿t Å¿onne of an Ea. a Baron, but not in legall proceedings Br. TreaÅ¿on 2. Coke 8-16. But the King may create them in the life of their AunceÅ¿tors Lords of the Parliament.

A Duke or other of the Nobilitie of a forraign Nation being named Duke in Letters of Å¿afe conduct, that makes him not Duke to be Å¿ued by that name in England, but a forraigne King ought Å¿o to be Å¿tiled, though he hath not merum imperium out of his owne Kingdome Cok 7.15. &c,

All the younger Sonnes of the King
of England are Earles by birth without other creation, and onely Lords by reputation,
A Lord of Ireland or Scotland, though he be poÅ¿t-natus, is but onely Lord in reputation.

div.head: Noble Women.
div.p: ALthough Noble Women may not Å¿it in Parliament in reÅ¿pect of their Sexes, yet are they in Law Peeres of the Realme, and may challenge all, Coke 8.53. or moÅ¿t of the former Priviledges.

But the opinions of Å¿ome have been,Crompt. IuÅ¿t de peace 85. that they cannot maintaine any Action upon the Statute of 2. R. 2. cap. 2. de Scand. Magnat. becauÅ¿e the Statute Å¿peakes onely of other Sexes.
If any of the Kings Å¿ervants within in the Checkroll conÅ¿pire the death of any Noble woman, that is not felony within the Statute of 3. H. 7.13.

div.head: Honourable women of three Å¿orts.
div.p: By Creation, DeÅ¿cent, Marriage.

H. 8. Created Anne Bullen MarchioneÅ¿Å¿e of Pembrooke, & King James Created the Lady Compton, Wife to Sir Thomas Compton, CounteÅ¿Å¿e of Buckingham, in the life of her Å¿aid Husband without any addition of honour to him. And formerly by Patents openly read in Parliament without any other inveÅ¿ture did Create Mary Å¿ole Daughter and heire of the late Baron of Aburgauen.
Camden 63.6. BaroneÅ¿Å¿e de le SpenÅ¿er.

Noble Women by DeÅ¿cent are thoÅ¿e to whom lands holden by Å¿uch Dignitie doe deÅ¿cend, or whoÅ¿e AnceÅ¿tors were Å¿eized of an eÅ¿tate deÅ¿cendable in their Titles of Dukedomes, &c. or thoÅ¿e whoÅ¿e AnceÅ¿tors were Å¿ummoned to the Parliament, by this an Inheritance doth accrue to their poÅ¿teritie.
They who take to Husband any Peere of the Realme, though they themÅ¿elves were not noble; ForteÅ¿cue, fol. 100.

QueÅ¿tion hath bin made whether the Dignitie of one Å¿uÌmoned to the Parliament dying without iÅ¿Å¿ue male may
deÅ¿cend to the female, but this may appeare by the former TreatiÅ¿e.

Concerning the title of Honour deÅ¿cendable to the Heire female, it is cleere that Å¿uch offices being of eÅ¿tate of inheritance doe deÅ¿cend, as the office of the high ConÅ¿tableÅ¿hip of England, challenged tempore H. 3. by the Duke of Buckingham was adjudged to deÅ¿cend to the Daughter of Humfrey Bohun Earle of Hereford. So the office of Earle MarÅ¿hall deÅ¿cended to the houÅ¿e of Norfolke, all which offices are as unfit to be exerciÅ¿ed by their Å¿exes, as unfit for them to be Å¿ummoned to the Parliament.
And if Å¿uch Title come in competition, the iÅ¿Å¿ue Å¿hall bee tried by record, and certified by the Kings Writ, and not by Jury, Coke 6.5 3.7. part 15.

Though all Daughters be Coperceners, and make but one Heire, yet in deÅ¿cent of Dignities it is otherwiÅ¿e, for they bee things entire, participating of Å¿uperioritie, therefore deÅ¿cendable onely to the eldeÅ¿t. And Å¿o is the Civill Law, yet there was a Judgement
tempore H. 3. touching the deÅ¿cent of the Earledome of CheÅ¿ter, Obijt. 17. H. 3. the Earle dying without iÅ¿Å¿ue, leaving his SiÅ¿ters his Heires; The Judgement was that it Å¿hould be divided equally among Coperceners; But this Judgement was held erroneous in that very age, Vide Bract. li. 2. cap. 34, fol. 76. hoc fuit injuÅ¿tum, &c. His reaÅ¿ons are, becauÅ¿e the honour of Chivalrie, chiefly conÅ¿iÅ¿ting in the Nobilitie may not be divided: for by multitude of partitions, the reputation of Honours in Å¿uch Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion muÅ¿t bee impaired, and the Å¿trength of the Realme being drawne into many hands by Å¿uch partition much infeebled. In which reÅ¿olution Britton by commandment, and in the name of E. 1. accorded fol. 187. The former Judgement was given about 17. H. 3. And the Writers of that time teÅ¿tifie, that it came holy unto Iohn Scot, Son of David Earle of Huntington, and AnguiÅ¿h and Maude the eldeÅ¿t SiÅ¿ter of the Å¿aid Randolph, if it were given upon the death of John Scot, who died without iÅ¿Å¿ue about 24. H. 3. yet it Å¿tood in force,
becauÅ¿e the King aÅ¿Å¿umed the Earledome to himÅ¿elfe upon other Å¿atiÅ¿faction to the coperceners, Mat. Par. 366. tamen vide Mills 75. & Guillem 28.

Hugh Lupus the firÅ¿t Earle of CheÅ¿ter, was by the Conquerour his vncle created into that dignitie, Mills 74.75. Coke 35.7 part 15. habend. fibi, &c. adeo libere per gladium Å¿icut Rex ipÅ¿e tenuit Angliam per Coronam, &c. he died without iÅ¿Å¿ue, and the Earldome divided among his 4. Å¿iÅ¿ters. If Å¿he be noble by birth, though Å¿he marry vnder her degree, Å¿he remaines noble, but thoÅ¿e innobled by marriage, and after marry with a man of meaner degree, utterly loÅ¿e her former dignitie, ForteÅ¿cue 100. Cooke 6.33.4.118.

It was the caÅ¿e of Ra. Howard EÅ¿quire, husband of the widow of the Lord Powes againÅ¿t the Dutches of Suffolke, the Writ naming her Ladie Anne Powes, Dyer 79. Å¿o alÅ¿o in Qu. Maryes times when the Dutches of Suffolke married Stokes bre. Bro. 146. digeÅ¿t lib. 1. Tit. 9. for the dignity accruing by marriage is but in
fait and not by any record, Coke 6.53. Coke 4.117. Cawells inÅ¿tit. lib. 1. Tit. 10.15.

So long Å¿hall a Dukes wife be called Dutches, and an Earles CounteÅ¿Å¿e, and enjoy all honours appertaining to that eÅ¿tate, with taÅ¿ting, kneeling, Å¿erving, &c. And a BaroneÅ¿Å¿e and Knights wife Å¿aluted Lady, Quamdiu matrimonium aut viduitas vxoris durant, except Å¿he elope, for as then every woman Å¿hall loÅ¿e her dower, Å¿o being advanced by titles of dignitie by that husband by Å¿uch elopement loÅ¿eth them.
If a Ladie which is married come through the forreÅ¿t, Å¿hee hath no priviledge by the Statute, but a DutcheÅ¿Å¿e or CounteÅ¿Å¿e during the time Å¿he is vnmarried may, Crompt. JuriÅ¿ dict. 167.
Such Ladies whether they be married or Å¿ole upon Indictment, Å¿hall be tried per Peeres by the Statute of 20. H. 6. cap. 9. it being a declaration of the common law. Coke 6.52.

By the Civill Law, Si filia Regis nubat alicui Domino, vel Comit. dicetur
tamen Å¿emper Regalis.

Among Noble women there is difference of degrees, and according to their qualities, the law gives Å¿peciall priviledges as followeth by the Stat. of 25. of E. 3, 2. it is high TreaÅ¿on to compaÅ¿Å¿e or imagine the death of the Queene, or to violate the Kings companion.

The Kings SpouÅ¿e is a Å¿ole perÅ¿on in law to purchaÅ¿e, &c. plead and be impleaded, Coke 4.23.6. Theboal lib. 1. cap. 4 24 E. 3.3.8. Bract. 363. And of Å¿uch acts of Parliament as concerne her, the Iudges ought to take notice, Coment. 231. a Coke 8.28. In Å¿ome caÅ¿es Å¿he Å¿hall have Prerogative as the King himÅ¿elfe. See the caÅ¿e of WardÅ¿hip 5. E. 3.4. Stamf. prerog. cap. 2.

The Qu. Wife to the King, or widow, Å¿hall not be amerced if Å¿he be non-Å¿uited, whereas all other Å¿ubjects Å¿hall, for Å¿he Å¿hall participate with the Kings prerogative, Coke 8.62. but not in all caÅ¿es, for the Å¿ubject Å¿hall not Å¿ue to her by Petition as to the King, 11. H. 4 67. Stamf. prerog. cap. 22.
AgainÅ¿t the King, Nullum tempus occurrit, otherwiÅ¿e of the Queene 18. E. 3.2. Philippa Regina Angl. Ibid. fol. 1. & 13. Stam. prerog. 18.
In 21. E. 3.6. A Protection was allowed againÅ¿t the Queene.

In a Writ of dower againÅ¿t IÅ¿abel Qu. of England mother to the then King, the Iudges were of opinion that Å¿hee was not to anÅ¿wer to any Writ, but Å¿aid they to the plaintife it behoveth you to go to her by Petition, to whom the Demandant Dixit graits, and prayed the court for a continuance of the action vntill Å¿hee might Å¿peake with the Queene; But they nor the Queenes Councell would agree that, the Qu. Å¿hould be accepted as anÅ¿werable 10. E 3.379.
The Wife of the Kings eldeÅ¿t Son hath Å¿ome prerogative not communicable to the Wives of other Noblemen, for by the Statute of 25. E. 3. It is high TreaÅ¿on to violate her.
DutcheÅ¿Å¿es alÅ¿o and CounteÅ¿Å¿es have Å¿peciall honour appertaining to their eÅ¿tates, as kneeling and taÅ¿ting, which things I leave to the Heraulds.

The Statute of 7. Iac. cap. 6. intituled an Act for the adminiÅ¿tring the oath of Allegiance requireth thoÅ¿e of 18. yeares or above to take the Å¿aid oath. The title is for adminiÅ¿tration of the Oath, &c. and reformation of married women RecuÅ¿ants.

div.head: Ladyes in Reputation.
div.p: THe Wife or Widow of the Å¿onne, and heire of a Duke or Earle, in the life of his Father, is a Lady by CurteÅ¿ie, and taketh place according to the antient time, as they have beene permitted by their Soveraigne Prince, and allowance of the Herauld. But in legall proceedings they are not to have Å¿uch Priviledge.
If a Noblewoman of Spaine come into England by a Å¿afe conduct, or, &c. And Å¿o Å¿tiled in the Å¿aid Letters, yet is Å¿hee but a Lady in reputation.
And EngliÅ¿h woman borne, taketh to Husband a SpaniÅ¿h or French Duke, though hee be made Denizen, yet Å¿hall Å¿he not beare the title of Dignitie in legall proceedings.

A German woman is married to the MarqueÅ¿Å¿e of Northampton, or, &c. unleÅ¿Å¿e Å¿he be made Denizen, Å¿hee cannot claime the priviledge or title of her Husband, no more then Å¿hee can claime Dower or Joynture.
An EngliÅ¿h woman doth take the Earle of Kildare in Ireland to her Husband, or if a Lord in Scotland, though hee be poÅ¿t natus, &c. their wives Å¿hall not aprticipate their HuÅ¿bands Dignities.

But if the King Create one of his Subjects naturalized by Parliament to be ViÅ¿count RocheÅ¿ter within England, and after Å¿ummon him to the Parliament by Writ, and aÅ¿Å¿igne him place there, by this is he made Peere of the Realme, and partakes with them of all Priviledges, and by conÅ¿equence his Wife, Widow and Children after him,E. of Angus in Scotland. 34. E. 3.35. Gilbert Humfrevils caÅ¿e.
But if an EngliÅ¿h man be made by the Emperour, Earle of the Empire, his Wife Å¿hall not beare that title, either according to law or reputation.

All Daughters of Dukes, MarqueÅ¿Å¿es
and Earles, are (by cuÅ¿tome long uÅ¿ed in the Kings Palace) to be named Ladies, and to have precedencie according to the degrees of their parents, and of this cuÅ¿tome the Law taketh notice.
But nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e in the Kings Courts of JuÅ¿tice, they beare not this title of Honour, no more then the Sons of Å¿uch noble perÅ¿onages. Brothers to Å¿uch Ladyes may doe.

div.head: The HypotheÅ¿is or particular QueÅ¿tion.
div.p: WHether the Dignitie of Aburgavenny, Sit conjuncta feodo, and Å¿uch as ought to deÅ¿cend to the Å¿peciall Heire male Å¿eized of the CaÅ¿tle, bearing the head of that Barony, and of the lands that make that Honour.
Or whether the Dignitie, Name and Stile, to be Baron of Aburgaven. ought to deÅ¿cend to the generall Heire male, who is not intereÅ¿Å¿ed in the Å¿aid CaÅ¿tle or honour.
For the more orderly proceeding herein to avoid confuÅ¿ion, and that every thing appeare concerning his queÅ¿tion in his proper perÅ¿on. There Å¿hall be Å¿hewed,

FirÅ¿t, that the Barony is a Barony by by tenure, a very antient Honour, and
no Barony by Writ onely, whereof will enÅ¿ue by the former Declaration in the treatiÅ¿e of Barony; That the dignitie and name de jure ought to go and deÅ¿cend with the CaÅ¿tle and Honour Å¿o holden, as long as the Å¿ame Å¿hall or may continue in the name, blood, and line of Å¿uch as are nobly deÅ¿cended, and may Å¿upport the Å¿ame. There Å¿hall be Proved

Secondly, That the Å¿aid Barony of Aburgav. and the name, title, and dignitie of Lord, and Barony of Aburg. de facto hath come and deÅ¿cended with the CaÅ¿tle, which make the honour of by the Å¿pace of 300. yeeres laÅ¿t paÅ¿t, in their noble Families in the blood of the HaÅ¿tings. 2. In the time of Beauchampe, and the time of Nevill, where the name by the Grace of God doth now, and long may continue, every which family having right to the Å¿aid CaÅ¿tle and honour, did lawfully beare the name and title of Lord Aburgav. and had place in Parliament accordingly. And therein Å¿hall be anÅ¿wered the objections made to the contrary.

div.head: That the Barony of Aburgavenny is a Barony by Tenure, and an antient Honour.
div.p:
AFter the Normans had conquered this Land, it was carefully obÅ¿erved by them as a matter of much moment, and a point of Å¿pecial policie to place upon the confines or borders of the Brittaines or Welch, not then Å¿ubdued, men of much matter, not onely Å¿ufficiently able to encounter the inrodes and invaÅ¿ions of the enemie, but alÅ¿o willing to make onÅ¿et on them, and to enlarge the conqueÅ¿t. TheÅ¿e men thus placed were of high blood, credit, and continuance among them, countreymen to the Normans, and in whoÅ¿e faith, and prowes the Conquerors repoÅ¿ed Å¿peciall confidence and truÅ¿t. And therfore in the territories given unto them to hold, the tenures were deviÅ¿ed to be very Å¿peciall and of great importance, and their Honours inriched with many priviledges,7. H 6.35. 18 E 2. AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿is 382 Fol. The Earle of CheÅ¿ter for the North border of Wales erected a County Palatine; And the Barons of
the middle part of the South Marches were adorned i a manner with a Palatine JuriÅ¿diction, having a Court of Chancery, and Writs onely among themÅ¿elves pleadable, to the intent that their attendance, might not thence be driven, for the proÅ¿ecuting of ControverÅ¿ies or quarrels in the Law. And as for the other part of the South Marches, they Å¿eemed Å¿ufficiently fenced with the River of Severne and the Sea.

The CaÅ¿tle of Aburgavenny taketh his name from the River of Gevenny, whereon it is Å¿cituate, and the BrittiÅ¿h word Abber, which Å¿ignifieth a Mouth, and is interpreted the Mouth of Gevenny, becauÅ¿e the CaÅ¿tle and Mouth of Aburgavenny is built neere the place where the Å¿aid River of Gevenny doth open it Å¿elfe to the end of the Uske; It is an antient FortreÅ¿Å¿e of old foundation: there or neere unto the place (as learned men doe probably, and upon many good circumÅ¿tances conjecture) where the Romans builded their Gabonium. It is the chiefeÅ¿t Townes of the County, called
the higher Guent, by the Romans called Ventum Gallinum, now parcell of the County of Monmouth.
This CaÅ¿tle, &c. was firÅ¿t given to be holden Per Baroniam Å¿ive grand Serjantie, the Å¿ervice whereof is of great importance, as appeareth by this Record following.

InquiÅ¿itio capt &c. At Aburgavenny, Ex buÌdelle EÅ¿ch 6. E 2. Mar. Wal.6. E. 2. upon the death of Jobn HaÅ¿tings found quod idem Iohannes tenuit caÅ¿trum, &c. De Rege in Capite per Å¿ervicium homagij wardi maritag. cum acciderit, & Å¿i _____ fuerit inter Regem Angl. & Principem Walliae dictus Iohannes debet cuÅ¿todire patriam de Operwent Å¿umptibus proprijs.

InquiÅ¿itio capt. apud Hereford upon a Writ of ad quod damnum, Ex Bundell. EÅ¿ch. 25. E. 3. Ex rot. Patent. 4. E. 1. num. 36. found quod non eÅ¿t ad damnum Regis nec, &c. Å¿i Rex conce â¢ at Priori, &c. de Aburg. quod ipÅ¿e duas acr. prat. vocat Weldelham, &c. quas de Lorentio de HaÅ¿tings nuper Comit. Pembrooke poÅ¿t Statutum de Mortmaine retinere poÅ¿Å¿it Å¿ibi & SucceÅ¿Å¿oribus Å¿uis, & dicunt quod praed. 2. acr. fuerunt de dominicis praedicti Comit. & tenentur immediate de Rege ut parcella
CaÅ¿tri quod tenetur de eo, & de nullo alio.

AlÅ¿o, that this Barony was of a very large Seignorie, and had petty Barons or Baronets holding thereof appeareth by Writ, 1. E. 1. for the more Å¿peedy gathering of 15th which was granted to him, towards his charge to the Holy land, which Writ is directed to the Tenants of the Å¿aid Barony, that they Å¿hould pay their part to Gremball Poneefote, and Henry de Bray appointed Collectours, directed in this manner.

Rex Abbatibus Prior. Baron. Mil. liberis hominbius & omnibus alijs Tenentibus de honor. Aberg. Salut. Cum ArchiepiÅ¿copi, EpiÅ¿copi, Abbat. Prior. Mil. & omnes alij de regno 15th. de bonis Å¿uis, qnibuÅ¿dam tamen rebus exceptis nobis liberaliter conceÅ¿Å¿erunt & benigne ad exonerationem debitorum in quibus diverÅ¿is mercatoribus de tempore quo moram in terra Å¿ancta geÅ¿Å¿imus obligamur, Nos, &c.
ObÅ¿er. 2 ObÅ¿ervatio Å¿ecunda, that the Title of Aberga. de facto hath deÅ¿cended with the CaÅ¿tle, &c.

William Conquerour gave the County of higher Guent, Hamline de Backlune. unto Hamline de Backlune, the Sonne of Drugo de Backlune a Norman, which builded the CaÅ¿tle and Priory of Abergavenny, and after aÅ¿Å¿ured the Å¿ame to Brian de Wallingford, Sonne of Eudo Earle of Brittaine, Sonne of Lucie younger SiÅ¿ter of the Å¿aid Hamline, by whom it was conveyed to Walter Å¿econd Sonne of Miles of GlouceÅ¿ter, tralt. of Glou. Brewes. Earle of Hereford, from him it came to his Brother Henry, and thence to the Families of Brewes Barons in the Marches of Wales, and from them to Cantelupe, Barons in the Å¿aid Marches.Cantelupe.

div.head: The the line of Hastings, owners of this CaÅ¿tle, and in reÅ¿pect thereof intituled, Barons of Aburgavenny.
div.p:
GEorge de Cantelupe Baron of Aburgavenny and Cant. the laÅ¿t of that name died without iÅ¿Å¿ue having two SiÅ¿ters,HaÅ¿tings. Ioan the eldeÅ¿t married to Henry HaÅ¿tings and MilliÅ¿cent, married to Eudo la Zouch. Henry HaÅ¿tings by his had iÅ¿Å¿ue Iohn, and becauÅ¿e
he did adhere to the Barons tempore H. 3. hee was impriÅ¿oned for Å¿even yeeres,Ed. Kelen Article 35. Rot. Cart. H 3. during which time hee died. And that Barony being in the Kings hands, he gave it to Peter de Sabandia in exchange for the Mannor of Baydenhall parcell of the Honour of Richmond which the Å¿aid King had given him; So that this Barony came now to the Earle of Richmond, EÅ¿c 8. E. 3. In Suffex. Ex rot. clauÅ¿. 2. E. 1 indoeÅ¿. memb. 12. as by an office found after the death of Iohn Britton Earle of Richmond, tempore E. 3. appeareth.

The Å¿aid Iohn HaÅ¿tings at the time of the death of Henry his Father, and Joan his mother, both which died in the life of the Å¿aid Geo. Cant. as alÅ¿o at the time of the death of the Å¿aid Geo. his Uncle was within age, and in ward to E. 1. during whoÅ¿e minoritie, there was a partition betweene the Å¿aid MilliÅ¿cent his Aunt, and the Å¿aid Iohn, by which the CaÅ¿tle, &c. of Aberg. then extended to the yeerely value of two hundred pounds, eighteene Å¿hillings and three pence, as alÅ¿o Kill Garren, St. Cleere, and other lands in England and Wales. And unto the
Å¿aid MilliÅ¿cent were allotted the CaÅ¿tle of Totnes in Devon, &c. Eyton in the County of Bedford, and Farringworth, &c. with divers other lands.

The Å¿aid Iohn came to full age,the firÅ¿t Iohn HaÅ¿tings, Baton of Aberg. 11. E. 1. and did his homage, and had his Livery as appeareth by Record, but by the Å¿ame Record appeareth, that the Barony of HaÅ¿tings was never redeemed according to the Edict Kellenworth, but granted to Peter de Sabandia, ClauÅ¿ 11. E. 1. Mem. 6. as aforeÅ¿aid.
This Iohn did lawfully beare the Title of Lord Abergavenny, by this partition.

The Å¿aid John being one of the Competitors for the Crowne of Scotland, with the reÅ¿t Å¿ubmitted himÅ¿elfe 19. E. 1. to the determination of the Å¿aid King as Supreame Lord of Scotland, which CommiÅ¿Å¿ion was framed in theÅ¿e words:

A tout crus, In magno Rot. ScaÌr. &c. Florence Comit. de Holland, Robert de BruÅ¿e, Å¿eigneur de VaÅ¿daum. Io. Balioll Seigneur de Badenaw, Patrick de Dumbar, Comite de la March, Ia. de VaÅ¿cye pur Å¿on pier Nich, de Seules, Gulielm. de RoÅ¿Å¿e: Salus
en dieu cum nous entendomus daver droit en Roylme de EÅ¿coce, & cel duel jure chalenger & avouer devant ceo
que pluis de pouer, juriÅ¿diction & reaÅ¿on eiÅ¿t de trier noÅ¿tre droit. Et le noble Prince Seig. Edward, &c. nous Å¿yant enforme per bo. & Å¿ufficient reaÅ¿on
que a luy come aver droit Soveraigne SuÌr seÌ du dit Roylme de EÅ¿coce, & la ConuÅ¿ance d'oyer trier & determin. noÅ¿tre droit, nous ne noÅ¿tre volunt Å¿ans nul maner de force ou diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿e de droit devant luy come Soveraigne SuÌr de la terre, &c. l'an de grace, 1291.
There was another like writing, whereby theÅ¿e competitors doe yeeld Å¿ome of the Kingdome of Scotland unto the Å¿aid E. 1. untill he Å¿hould determine the controverÅ¿ie.
After the Å¿entence given by E. 1. for John Balioll, who afterwards adhered to the French againÅ¿t England.

Whereupon Ed. 1. proÅ¿ecuting war againÅ¿t Scotland, the Pope intermedling, a Parliament was proclaimed to be held at Lincolne. 29. E. 1. where it wass agreed that the King Å¿hould write to the Pope touching his right
to that Crowne, and the wrong offered him. And that the Nobility Å¿hould write, that they neither could, nor ought to Å¿uffer,Nota that the King of England Å¿hould referre the Å¿ame to the Popes Å¿entence, they Å¿ubÅ¿cribing their names and titles of Honour, among which was the Å¿aid Iohn HaÅ¿tings name in this manner, Iohannes Dominus de Aburgavenny.

In 16. E. 1. the King purpoÅ¿ing to go to France, Ex Rot. mal. 17. E 1. in dorÅ¿. charged the Lords Marchers of Wales to be reÅ¿ident upon their Baronies, fearing the invaÅ¿ion of the Welch. and Anno 17. in the Rebellion of RiÅ¿e ap Meredocke the King being in France, directeth his Writ unto the Å¿aid Marchers under the TeÅ¿t. Edmundi fratris Å¿ui. And among other the Barons there named as Ed. de Mortimer, Roger Mortimer, Pet. Corbet. Roger le Strange, Fulk Fitzwarren, Galfrid de Canmyl, William Mortimer, Guy de Brian, Iohn de HaÅ¿tings, Ra. de Tony, William de BruÅ¿e, Iohn TregouÅ¿e, Bogok Nevill, Ric. Fiz-Allen, & Io. Fitz-Reginald, and all Barons Marchers.

Againe 20. E. 1. When therer was a great quarrell between Gilbert de Clare, 20. E. 1.14 in recept. Scacar. Earle of GlouceÅ¿ter and Hereford, and Humfrey de Bohum, late E. of Hereford and EÅ¿Å¿ex, whereupon murders, &c. had beene committed in their lands in Brecnocke.

A CommiÅ¿Å¿ion was awarded to the BiÅ¿hop of Ely, William de Valence, the Kings vncle, Io. de Mettingham one of the Iudges, and unto Robert de Hereford, to heare and determine the Å¿ame. In which CommiÅ¿Å¿ion the Å¿aid Iohn HaÅ¿tings was one In which the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners would have had the Å¿aid Barons to have beene Å¿worne to make preÅ¿entment thereof, which they refuÅ¿ed, Å¿tanding upon their priviledge, and therfore the EnqueÅ¿t was impannelled of others.

P. 23. E. 1. The Å¿aid Iohn was Å¿ummoned ot the Parliament,Som. Parliamen. Anno 24. E. 1. Som. Parl. a. 35. E. 1. which was to be holden the Sunday next after the feaÅ¿t of St. Martin, as alÅ¿o to a Parliament at Carlile, 35. E. 1.

It will be objected that Iohn his father was Å¿ummoned in 49. H. 3. and therfore in regard thereof and not
in reÅ¿pect of this Barony was this Iohn Å¿ummoned.

It is true that Henry HaÅ¿tings was Å¿ummoned it 49.
